name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The first item is the debate on six motions for a resolution on the persecution of democratic opposition in Venezuela [(2014/2998(RSP)].

name: Luis de GRANDES PASCUAL
text: Author. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, for a Spaniard to have to speak ill of a country like Venezuela is almost a pain. We have old affections, old historical ties and feelings between the two peoples that are never going to disappear. But things have gone a long way. The fact that four large political groups—the largest in the House—have agreed on such a strong resolution in terms of disqualification from political action such as That of President Maduro in relation to the persecution of the opposition, the fact that the United Nations Committee against Torture has issued disqualification in clear and net terms that there is no freedom of expression , that there is no independence from the judiciary, that there are concrete tortures... all of this indicates, of course, that it's not just words. We wonder how far Mr Maduro is going to abuse our patience and how long he will believe that he has legitimacy, even if he has been democratically elected, to disqualify and insult a democratic president like President Aznar, calling him a "coupista" or telling him other lindnesses, this epigon of coup, which was and which had to be pardoned! We wish Venezuela the greatest of prosperity; we wish the people of Venezuela to have a democratic path in peace and to find a way in which, with Europe, we can help this better future.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Author. - (DE) Mr President, I would like to thank Since the 2013 presidential election, the situation in Venezuela has deteriorated dramatically. The situation is becoming increasingly difficult for opposition groups. Arrests are the order of the day, and the arrest of opposition leader Leopoldo Lopez is the most spectacular case of this. The UN High Commissioner has expressed to the public his grave concern about the situation and has noted systematic violations of human rights. The country is divided. This rift runs right through the families, and it is indeed high time that the current Venezuelan government ended this disgraceful chapter and began a peaceful dialogue with the opposition. Above all, all innocent detainees must be released without delay, the right to freedom of speech and assembly must be guaranteed and the independence of the judiciary must be restored.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Author. Mr President, I can only join the previous speakers. What began in February as a student protest for greater security prompted President Maduro's regime to forcibly crush all dissident voices. Ten months later, we count dozens of victims and as many as 1 400 civilians await their trial. Anyone who tries to express himself on the Internet risks prison sentences of up to five years. There is no longer a rule of law in Venezuela. President Maduro, as Chavez's successor, is trying to keep the population under a heavy-handed thous state, in a country saddled with a disastrous legacy: a nationalized economy with widespread corruption and inflation of more than 60 percent. Perhaps we should remember to follow the U.S. Congress and impose sanctions against President Maduro and his entourage. Initially look at those persons in the regime who have violated human rights, no longer admit them to the European Union and freeze their financial assets. Finally, this Parliament must strongly condemn Venezuela's democratic deficit and work for the release of hundreds of peaceful demonstrators, their leaders and all political prisoners, including the democratically elected President of the Parliament, Maria Corina Machado.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Author. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on the Venezuelan issue, as is often the case in such cases, I perceived during the negotiation and tabling of amendments, a question more of 'cheering' than of a real problem. It is clear that there is a problem of democracy and human rights violations in Venezuela. However, we still cannot look at it in a truly clear and objective way because we have, on the one hand, supporters of President Maduro and therefore pro-government and, on the other hand, the supporters of the opposition, which, however, could be an opposition that is not exactly spontaneous but induced by some western third-party power. So I believe that we should learn and try to look at situations like this in a more fearful and impartial way, perhaps by finding concrete third-party bodies that are mainly concerned with protecting the Venezuelan population and the human rights of the inhabitants of Venezuela.

name: Fernando MAURA BARANDIARÁN
text: Author. - Mr President, this resolution comes at the right time. Today I can say proudly that the European Parliament has risen to the task and that, at a historic moment, it has been able to respond strongly to the demands of Venezuela's democratic opposition. However, despite the importance and forcefulness of the text we are voting on today, we cannot fall into the mistake of thinking that we have already done everything we could. On the basis of this resolution, we must, we must work more closely if possible for the Venezuelan Government to rectify and stop, once and for all, the systematic violations of human rights and the fundamental freedoms of political opponents. However, if that correction does not occur, on behalf of the ALDE Group, I assure you that we will consider all possibilities for that Government to change its behaviour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: Author. - Mr President, some Members use democracy and human rights in accordance with their interests. This Resolution is an example of political instrumentalization of human rights against the people, against the democratically elected course in Venezuela. Everything has been attempted: coup d'etion, oil sabotage, economic warfare and media warfare. And now, violence. Are these your peaceful students? I see a long gun here. I see a weapon of war here. I see a mortar launch here. (The speaker has been showing different photographs.) What would those who will vote in favour of this Resolution say if a hooded man murdered an agent of the order in their country? Eleven have been killed in Venezuela! In Spain, the People's Party has passed, against all the opposition, a law that restricts protest but, for Venezuela, the "funnel law". Whatever you do, use the lies you use, you will not be able to twist the sovereign course democratically elected by the Venezuelans. (Applause)

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, the Venezuelan regime is trying to silence the opposition by incarceration. Several thousand people, including politicians, journalists and students, are imprisoned after the unfortunate events of February. One of them is Leopoldo López, a prominent opposition politician.  I support this resolution because i am so in charge of historical experience. Even here, in the countries of the former Soviet bloc, communist regimes sought to silence the opposition by persecution and incarceration. That is why the support that came from democratic countries was so important to us, then 25 years ago. And I think Venezuela still needs that democratic support today. Free Leopold López, free the thousands of Venezuelans who are like him.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group– Mr President, in our view, a democracy cannot be dissociated from a rule of law, and a rule of law implies some fundamental things: respect for the principle of separation of powers, respect for individual autonomy and freedom of expression. And who has to ensure in the first instance respect for the rules of the rule of law is the one who momentarily governs a country. That is why the Socialist Group has actively participated in a joint effort to approve such an initiative. But having said that, it is also important to say that the situation in Venezuela is a situation of enormous complexity. We are absolutely opposed to the prospect of sanctions. We consider this an absolute exaggeration. It has nothing to do with situations like the one that has now been mentioned. What is happening today in Venezuela has nothing to do with what happened in the Soviet Union once. And we also call for the opposition in Venezuela to manifest themselves peacefully, which has not always been the case, as has been said here. That is why we will approve this proposal. We participate in the elaboration of it, because for us there are fundamental principles, which is the principle of respect for the rule of law, and it is clear that we are witnessing situations in Venezuela that objectively conflict with this principle, but at the same time we do not want to fail to make a more general reference to the situation in Venezuela.  Venezuela is, from our point of view, a democratic society, where there are elections, but it is a democratic society where today and at the moment there are serious problems that have to be countered. And that is why the European Parliament is taking its full part of it. (The speaker agrees to answer a question under the "blue card" procedure in accordance with Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: blue card question. – Mr President, I just wanted to add one thing and show that the work we are doing from Parliament in relation to Venezuela is important. It is quite decisive, in the sense that we are joining forces, but we are not yet sufficiently highlighting something that is important, which is the recognized political persecution. The question is: Mr Assis, are we going to insist that the European Union and the countries of the European Union, such as Belgium, which have recognised Venezuelans as political as political assilados, to make the Union precisely aware of this political persecution?

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. – Mr President, I believe that the vote that we are likely to adopt in a short time clearly advances in this direction: the recognition that there are situations that are reputable, the way the opposition is treated in Venezuela. This is even explicit in the vote, in fact according to united nations resolutions itself.  Now, what I also want to point out here, because it seems very important to me, is that we should not confuse things. In Venezuela there have been democratic elections over the years. What we stand for is that this is not enough to truly affirm a democracy. A democracy is not just about electoral acts. A democracy also implies respect for the rules of the rule of law, and when there is disrespect, in Venezuela or wherever, we must express our position.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The arrest in February of several students on the pretext of criminal activity after they had taken part in peace demonstrations two weeks earlier led to a wave of protests that took the form of demonstrations across the country. The protests were joined by opposition leader Leopoldo López, who has been accused by the Venezuelan authorities of insuding protests. However, he himself quickly handed himself into the hands of the judiciary, calling him an unjust and one who sends to prison seeking peaceful and democratic change in the venezuelan system.  The detention, arrest and imprisonment to this day of Leopoldo López is an unjustified, illegal and unlawful act. Moreover, he and other fellow prisoners belonging to the democratic opposition are subjected to cruel, inhuman and degrading treatment, which respects the dignity of the human person and denies respect for human rights. It is time for the international community to take action against the Nicolás Maduro regime and contribute to respect for freedom, democracy, the rule of law and human rights in the country.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, we are witnessing a severe deterioration of the rights of the people of Venezuela. We can't just stand aside, waiting for the situation to get worse. I therefore ask the Council to begin to consider as an option specific sanctions against officials of the Maduro Government. I'm horrified by the way the regime treats its people. Venezuelans who exercise their democratic right to peacefully speak out against the government's failed policy are exposed to systematic repression and brutality by security forces. I call on the competent authorities to release all political prisoners who have been arbitrarily detained and who have been denied fair treatment, including but not including Leopoldo López and María Machado. We can only tolerate opposition leaders being abused and punished and that in Venezuela there is no operational judiciary that can fairly investigate and prosecute such situations.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, the starting point of this year's bloody conflict in Venezuela was the far-right's attempt to overthrow the democratically elected Maduro government by force. So instead of the dominant political forces in the European Parliament inaugurating the Venezuelan government, in fact, using selective data from the report of the United Nations Commissioner for Human Rights al-Hussein, they would do better to deal with the corresponding report by the United Nations Commissioner for Human Rights, Shefas Lumina, which finds systematic violations of fundamental rights in Greece in the Memorandum, because of the policies of exterminating austerity imposed by the Troika and ECOFIN. And instead of lessons in democracy in Venezuela, they would do better to show greater respect for democratic processes in the Member States of the Union and to stop attempts to blackmail the consciences of Greek MPs and voters with the threats of bankruptcy, exit from the eurozone and the like that we have heard in recent days. (Applause) (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a 'blue card' (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Klaus BUCHNER
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". It is right that in Venezuela the opposition is using force and illegalising. But is it also right to deal with illegal action by terror and torture? I would like an answer to that.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr Buchner, I would like to thank Mr Buchner for his work on Terror and torture are wrong, regardless of which side they come from. But we have legal proceedings here against people who have committed crimes in Venezuela.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I have to say that what we are witnessing is a misuse of Article 135, because here we do not intend to prosecute a possible violation of human rights, but to make a general case against a democratically elected Government: because I no longer know how many resolutions venezuela this Parliament has made. Here are some Members who are able to applaud with their ears the European Union's cooperation with totalitarian regimes and who have with Venezuela a fixation on the fact that their government is politically coloured. If there is any kind of human rights violation in Venezuela, it must be treated with the same measuring stick that we do in many other cases, and this is not the case. What there is is a widening and a general cause—and I can't agree and my group disagrees with that. So, what I have to say is that I deeply regret, again, this exercise in hypocrisy. We did not want to participate in eer the debate or the amendments because we do not agree that this Resolution should be presented. And, of course, I can announce our opposing vote to you. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Karol KARSKI
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – It has been stated here that such a condemnation of the Venezuelan Government is unjustified. I therefore have a question for you: do you accept the inhuman and degrading treatment of the imprisoned opposition? Human excrement is thrown into the target of Leopoldo López and other arrested opposition activists in the middle of the night. During this time, electricity and water are cut off so that prisoners cannot wash it off. In addition, the loudest music with loud hymns in honor of Chávez is played as loudly as possible: "Chávez is alive, the fight continues." Do you accept such actions?

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: "blue card" response. – Mr Karski, the cases we need to deal with, we can deal with them. But all I'm saying is that I demand the same measuring stick we use for other countries. And the text is a general cause: a clear general cause against a democratically elected government. Next time, if there are any specific cases, present the specific case and we discuss it, but just as they do with other countries. I think there are eight resolutions in the case of Venezuela: it is a ingrañamiento against a government because they do not like its political color. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Javier NART
text: blue card question. – Mr Urtasun, do you think it is reasonable for the rapporteur of the United Nations Human Rights Committee, that the rapporteur of the United Nations Committee against Torture, that the rapporteur of the United Nations Working Group on Arbitrary Detention... that Venezuela's extraordinary and significant absence and march of the Inter-American Court of Human Rights means a fear on the part of Venezuela and, secondly, a real reality to be condemned? And I tell you something else. Look, I apply that to all places where human rights violations occur. What I do not understand is that you refrain from condemning the condemnable, for thinking that others do not condemn what is also condemnable.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: "blue card" response. – Javier, that's not it. I will always condemn human rights violations wherever necessary. I've been in human rights associations for many years. That's not it, Javier.  This is a general cause. And you and I weren't here in the last legislature, but they were made I don't know how many resolutions about Venezuela, because there are Members in this House who are trying to get tangled up. It's not that, I don't agree.

name: Amjad BASHIR
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I would like to take this opportunity to urge the Obama Administration to open a dialogue with Venezuela, just as it has in the case of Cuba. Let us remove the excuses and alibis of the regime in Venezuela, which they use to curtail the freedom of the press, rig elections, prevent true democracy and carry out other repressions. Venezuela has to realise that it can no longer sustain the economy because, world-wide, the price of oil is in free-fall. It is expecting 60% inflation this year. It can no longer afford the generous welfare benefits it has promised its citizens. The US has to realise, as it has done with Cuba, that it cannot – and must not – suppress the aspirations of another sovereign state. I wish to say Merry Christmas and Happy New Year to all the Members here.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: Mr President, I am deeply concerned by the constant worsening of the political situation in Venezuela. This country has a heightened responsibility to comply with the rule of law, having just become a member of the UN Security Council.  The economic and social crisis there is a direct outcome of growing political and ideological intolerance. Massive protests have been countered by the disproportionate use of force, the arrest of the opposition leader Leopoldo López and the scandalous suspension of opposition congressmen. But above all, it is unpardonable that almost 40 demonstrators have been killed by pro-government armed groups. This is not a rule of law state.  We express our solidarity with the people who are trying to bring Venezuela back to democracy and risking their lives. We ask the EU and Ms Mogherini to call for the immediate release of protestors and political prisoners.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: Mr President, apart from the wrongdoings in the drafting of the Resolution, and in particular the bias of some of its paragraphs, the truth is that all political and social actors in Venezuela must engage in constructive dialogue, which means the cessation of all violence and the undertaking of a dialogue that puts peace and allows the expression of the right of assembly and demonstration without any violence. But the Venezuelan authorities must cease their arbitrary detentions. It should be noted, notably, the case of Leopoldo López, who has been imprisoned for ten months after an arrest that has been described as arbitrary by the United Nations Committee against Torture, by the United Nations Working Group on Arbitrary Detention and by the United Nations Human Rights Committee. It is therefore imperative to end the dejudicilization of justice in Venezuela, which keeps someone in a military prison in a case that should in no case be subject to military jurisdiction. I conclude by quoting Moisés Naím, who in his article "Postales from Venezuela" said that the real conflict that divides Venezuela at the moment is not the one that confronts the defenders of capitalism with the defenders of socialism, but those who defend violence as a political tool and the arbitrary persecution of opponents and those who are willing to sacrifice to prevent it.

name: Bas BELDER
text: Mr President, there is a great deal that can be said in just one sentence. That's what the united democratic opposition in Venezuela did less than a week ago. Her position is that the regime of our country can claim that it has democratised impunity. That's a huge conviction. The Venezuelan opposition deserves our full support in its legitimate pursuit of a democratic rule of law at home. In the meantime, the Maduro regime stands out in a very different way in a purely negative sense. Venezuela's Jewish community has been reduced to just 7,000 members due to the regime's brutal anti-Semitism. In Venezuela, there is a situation of anti-Semitism without Jews. What the left has to answer, I'd like to hear that.

name: Renate WEBER
text: Mr President, today in Venezuela many civic and political opposition leaders are in prison. Leopoldo López is just the most well-known, but almost 100 young activists are in prison and more than 2 000 are under investigation, all for exercising their right to protest against a government which has led the country to the brink of disaster. President Maduro and his government must understand that, in a democracy, we compete fairly with our opponents. We do not jail them, with a view to ending their political careers and even lives. The UN Human Rights Commissioner called for the release of these prisoners, and so did the Committee against Torture and the Organisation of American States. Now the European Parliament is calling for their release. We cannot all be considered part of a conspiracy against Venezuela. Quite the opposite, we want a democratic path for the Venezuelan people; we want their safety and prosperity.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: Mr President, violent acts, destruction of public property, such as burning down institutions, health centres and kindergartens – in fact, today is a lady whose baby daughter died in a fire at a children's daycare centre, because the order that was to burn – murders of people at close range and indiscriminately are certainly serious crimes and in any of our countries those who committed them , organized or encouraged are tried and punished and no one would admit to putting this into question. But in Venezuela, which many Members here have forgotten that it has been independent for over 200 years, you say, the victims are not those, they are the ones who caused these deaths. And the people who died and those who were injured do not deserve any mention from you. At the moment, 34 people are being held in Venezuela, accused of serious crimes, and 14 law enforcement officers, who are also accused of abuse of force. And what is required is respect for the judicial authorities of a sovereign state which must be treated as equal, not the shameful treatment of neocolonial nature to which the European Parliament is bold. The adoption of this resolution today means the instrumentalisation of the European Parliament by a violent extremist group that is far from representing the majority of the Venezuelan opposition.

name: Carlos ITURGAIZ
text: Mr President, the situation in Venezuela is an international emergency. The Maduro Government, a continuing government of Hugo Chávez, remains a dictatorial and caudillist government whose objectives are to crush the opposition, trampl on human rights, shelter terrorists, end press freedom, and destroy the Venezuelan people by oppressing and impoverishing them. The Republic of Venezuela is, in fact, a republic of horrors, where one pursues, condemns itself and imprisons those who do not think as Maduro wants. Media are persecuted and shut down for not dancing to the sound that marks and orders chavista communist doctrine. The Venezuelan people are desabased, persecuted and subjected to the fear of the ultra-Chavistas. These are no longer times of words, but of actions, and from the European institutions, the Government of Venezuela must be required to stop its escalation of anti-democratic repression that it has under way. Someday, Mr President, I am sure that Venezuela will emerge from this horrible Chavista nightmare and will be a truly democratic country full of freedoms. And from the European People's Group we will work to make this a reality. And I regret that those who defend the Chavista Government of Venezuela from Spain, such as Mr Pablo Iglesias and those of Podemos, have had the cowardice of not coming to this House to debate and have been absent: they are not and do not speak, they say absolutely nothing.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: Mr President, the European Union has asserted itself in international politics as an actor dedicated to promoting democracy and protecting human rights. We can say with conviction that respect for democratic procedures and principles, as well as respect for human rights, is not only a political priority in the Union's external action, but the very reason for its existence. In these circumstances, we cannot fail to look with concern at the situation in Venezuela, where the rule of law, democratic principles and mechanisms, as well as the essential rights belonging to each human being are persistently violated. I therefore support the adoption of this resolution. I think it is important for the European Union to send the message to the need for the principles of democracy and the rule of law, just as I think it is important that the persecution and arbitrary adjudication of opposition representatives in Venezuela, as well as the extrajudicial use of violence, must stop. At the same time, I believe it is important for Venezuela to take important steps towards guaranteeing the right to free opinion and free association. It is also important that all the European institutions are involved in this effort, and I agree with the initiators of the resolution that the High Representative must play a much more visible role in this subject.

name: Andrew LEWER
text: Mr President, I had hoped to speak to highlight the case of María Corina Machado today, but I now focus on the comments made by the Venezuelan Ambassador at the Mercosur delegation yesterday where he stated that Leopoldo López was guilty of a range of offences and then said he would receive a fair trial. The absurdity of that, the sign that the chance for a fair trial is fading away in Venezuela, was crystal clear. The regime was exposed from its own lips, and the antics of this regime, the ‘Vos No Sos’ and talking to little birds, would be comic were it not for the serious human rights abuses and impoverishment of its people that are taking place. As for the ludicrous comments made by the far left here today about respect and neo-colonialism, I simply have to say this: shame on you for those shameful comments.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: Mr President, I would like to express my solidarity and appreciation to the people of Venezuela. To the people who have freely and democratically expressed their support for the ongoing revolutionary process through the greater succession of electoral acts, referendums – acts that are recognised as valid by international observers. Jimmy Carter himself, former president of the United States, has classified Venezuela's democratic process as exemplary, I quote. So instead of giving lessons in democracy to Venezuela, we should reflect on how the government has put the country's resources at the service of the majority, not just some.  How the government ended illiteracy, how it improved human development rates, how it reduced hunger and poverty, how it distributed homes to those living on the street. I understand the blind anger of those who see their hatred of alternative development projects here, but history will do its justice.

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe is linked to Venezuela by deep historical ties. As a major player in regional integration in Latin America, Venezuela has the potential to contribute to the region's economic growth and prosperity, or at least it would have the potential.  However, the exacerbation of tensions and political polarisation in the country is of deep concern. 2014 was a turbulent year that brought pro- and anti-government protesters to the squares. Since February, the European Union has expressed, through a series of declarations, its concern at the increasing polarisation and the increase in violent incidents. We expressed our concern about the imprisonment of students and politicians and appealed to the government and opposition leaders, students and civil society in the country to work side by side to find a consensual solution. We have called on all parties to engage in political dialogue and to condemn violence.  It is worrying to note that there is no progress towards much-needed reconciliation. The scenarios of confrontation that are also expected for the future are a cause for concern. The European Union had expressed appreciation to President Maduro for the commitment he made in his inaugural address in 2013 on building an inclusive nation. The country's current tensions, however, remind us that Venezuela is far from having overcome internal divisions. It is a complex situation that appeals to the sense of responsibility of the government and opposition parties to come together to find a way out. Only an inclusive approach will make it possible to take the necessary decisions. We urge the government that won the 2013 elections to take the lead to bring the country back to Unity and find a compromise solution. Venezuela is facing not only political problems but also serious economic, social and security problems: rising inflation, increasingly deficient basic consumer goods, civil tensions and record levels of crime and insecurity. The dramatic fall in world oil prices is also likely to further aggravate the situation and severely affect the country's ability to meet its 2015 targets. Recently, President Maduro announced a series of cuts in public spending. As the political crisis continues, the government is in danger of failing to find the necessary public consensus in support of anti-crisis measures. Venezuela's role in the region could also be affected, as unasur Secretary-General Ernesto Samper recently recalled in a speech in Brasilia. Parliament's resolution rightly recalls the situation of protest leaders, including students, opposition politicians and all those arbitrarily detained. The Venezuelan authorities have a duty to ensure rapid and impartial investigations and to verify the allegations in full compliance with the law. It is disreciable that a number of legal proceedings continue to be delayed. We will continue to follow closely the case of political opponents such as Leopoldo Lopez and the four students who were inquire at the same time. The European Union stands ready to intensify relations with Venezuela at both regional and bilateral level. It is in the name of a real and heartfelt friendship that we remind Venezuela that stability and progress can only be achieved through an inclusive dialogue based on respect for human rights and freedom of expression. Dialogue is the only way to ensure reconciliation throughout the political spectrum.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place after the debates. Written statements (Article 162 of the Regulation)

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: in writing. – The serious altercations that have happened in recent months and the country's current political situation call for European denunciation and the call on the Government of Venezuela to comply with the universal laws of democracy and ensure the application of fundamental human rights. However, I would like to stress that, in my opinion, the resolution which is expected to be adopted this morning does not exactly respond to my interpretation of what is happening in Venezuela, and is not balanced with regard to the demands that this Parliament must make to all Venezuelan political actors. In this regard, I believe that the recitals lack a more explicit reference to the responsibilities of the conveners of the demonstrations on their peaceful development and that all opposition groups in Venezuela must be demanded to exercise their legitimate right to political opposition peacefully, always and everywhere.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: , in writing.– Jailing government's political opponents and Kafka-like trials that we see in Venezuela, shows that Venezuelan government openly carries out tactics of an authoritarian regime. The case of Leopoldo Lopez is merely one instance of an unfair, illegal and politically motivated trial. The national court has not been impartial in his case. All but one of Mr. López’s 65 defense witnesses was rejected whilst 108 of the government’s witnesses were admitted. So far, no evidence has been presented against the opposition leader. It is important that the European Parliament to speak loudly in this case - condemn political persecution and the imprisonment of democratic opposition in Venezuela and call for their release. I had a chance to meet Leopoldo personally some time ago, so this is also my personal call. I support his views and encourage him in his political fight for democratic Venezuela.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. – Venezuela's crackdown on opposition leader and presidential candidate Enrique Capriles Radonsky is one of those that is sparking our emotions. It would be difficult to find a person among us who would be happy about such persecutions. The problem is, someone's counting on our reaction like this. He's counting on the public's emotions. And he wants to reverse the outcome of the election, overthrow the government of President Nicolás Maduro. I think the time has slowly come to openly say whether we are in for democracy or for non-colonial control of the rest of the world. Whether we will be offended by every defense of the outcome of an election that did not turn out to our wishes, and pour oil into the fire on every Maidan. Whether our human rights advocacy will take the form of bombing Tripoli and tacitly looking at the fascists in Odesa. Whether we despise the will of the majority at any time will suit any of the powerful and wealthy. There are times when a decision needs to be made. When our speech must be YES, YES – NO, NO. And I say NO to the further spread of chaos in the world. Let's not just look for guilt with others. Let's look into our own ranks. And let's say NO to the spread of chaos. Let's say YES to a stable Venezuela and a free Latin America.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The next item is the debate on seven proposals for a Resolution on Mauritania, in particular the case of Biram Dah Abeid [(2014/2999(RSP)].

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Author. - (DE) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for the excellent work he has Mauritania officially abolished slavery in 1981, and has been a criminal in the country since 2007. But in practice, slavery persists. Non-governmental organizations such as IRA Mauritania and other organizations, such as SOS Esclaves, bring cases of slavery to the public. The Mauritanian Government would therefore be well advised to take the work of these organisations seriously, even to see them as support in the fight to eradicate slavery. But the situation shows the opposite. Today, with this resolution, we call on the government to put an end to its action against anti-slavery activists. In particular, we call for the release of the recently re-arrested anti-slavery activists, in particular Mr Biram Dah Abeid, and condemn their arrest. Anyone who wants to fight slavery in Mauritania must also fight the poverty of the many enslaved people. This includes giving the Haratin group the opportunity to own land – land on which the Haratin has been working for generations and which they have cultivated. The Mauritanian Government is called upon to take serious action here.  International companies operating in Mauritania are also called upon to ensure that they do not use forced or child labour. It is certainly also the EU's task to ensure that it does not tolerate slave labour in any way, for example in trade relations with Mauritania and not indirectly.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Author. Mr President, discussing Mauritania and Biram Dah Abeid today is not easy for me. The reason I raised this subject, and if it is not simple for me, is because, unlike other subjects we have dealt with here, I have met several times with Biram Dah Abeid, who is an activist engaged in the fight against slavery in Mauritania. So it is with some emotion that I deal with this case here. I call, in a clear and strong way, on the Mauritanian authorities to release this man, who is fighting for the good of his country. More generally, I believe that Mauritania must move away from this logic of denial of a reality that is very heavy and it must assume the consequences of slavery, that it deals with these issues as soon as possible, in order to give a better life to the Mauritanian people.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Author - Despite the fact that 2014 is written, there is a state in the world where only the so-called modern-day slavery that we are witnessing is unfortunately also present in developed countries. There are real slaves living in Mauritania – people who are the property of other people who have absolute power over them, who decide their lives and deaths. I unequivocally condemn this situation. Tolerating such unacceptable practices, which have even been prohibited by law in this country for several years. I ask the Government of Mauritania to release the wrongfully detained fighter for the abolition of the slavery of Biram Dah Ababa, whose trial has reportedly begun today. If convicted, this activist will not only be a great injustice, but also a blow to the thousands of slaves for whom freedom is fought. I call on the Mauritanian Government to respect not only human rights, but also its own laws. It is impossible to tolerate such a situation, and for my part I can state that there is no economic interest that would make me turn a blind eye to this inhumane action.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Author. - (DE) Mr President, I would like to thank Some of us have had the opportunity in recent years to meet Biram Dah Arbeid, the tireless fighter against slavery officially abolished but still practised in his country, Mauritania. As the son of former slaves, he advocates a modern, democratic Mauritania that respects human rights, not only on the international stage, but above all in his homeland. He and his associates were arrested as part of an awareness campaign to educate people about the rights. He is accused of belonging to an illegal organisation and could even be punished with death. We must make every effort to ensure that these people are released immediately and that Mauritania stands unequivocally in its obligations under international treaties. I hope that this resolution will also initiate a dialogue with the Mauritanian Government in order to put an end to these conditions at long last.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Author. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, according to a recent report by Amnesty International in Mauritania, a very poor country of 3.5 million people, it is estimated that there are 700 000 people forced to live under a master. In Mauritania, slavery, used as a real weapon of power, is still an atrocious reality and there are several forms of it: domestic, linked to unpaid work and children, who are sexually violated, abused from birth, abused and used as slaves by descent, being children of slaves. Being a slave in Mauritania therefore means being born slaves, owned by the white master. Today's situation is even more serious than in the past. Every day, slave-born human beings are discriminated against, humiliated and castrated into their human rights. On November 11, 2014, at least nine well-known anti-slavery activists were arrested and transferred to various detention centers in the southern city of Rosso. Among them is Biram Dah Ould Abeid, a sort of Mauritanian Mandela. His fault? Fight against this tragedy. The European Union should use all its strength and demand that the Mauritanian authorities release all prisoners of conscience immediately.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: Author. Mr President, on behalf of the ALDE group, I would like to publicly express our support for this resolution, in that it calls for the immediate release of Mr Abeid and abolitionist activists and unequivocally condemns the slavery that continues to be practised in Mauritania. However, I regret, following the opposition of the representatives of the two major groups, the absence in this resolution of several paragraphs that we had requested. We had proposed a paragraph asking the Mauritanian government to sign and ratify the protocol on the status of the African Court of Justice and Human Rights. This was denied! We had asked for a paragraph asking the Commission to engage in a political dialogue with the Mauritanian government on respect for human rights, on the basis of Article 8 of the Cotonou agreements. This was denied! We had asked for the Commission to include in this resolution a request to the Commission to launch formal consultations, in accordance with Article 96, on any violation of human rights. This was denied! I have not understood these refusals, Mr President, which were justified in the negotiations we have conducted, by the argument of authority on the size of the groups, which seems to me to be the most painful argument.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: Author. - Mr President, Article 4 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, which we have just commemorated, prohibits all forms of slavery. Now, 66 years later, 21 million people are victims of forced labour worldwide—4.5 million of them victims of forced sexual exploitation. We must also point out the neoliberal policies that we are experiencing as a threat to human rights — also for Article 4 — throughout the world, including the European Union. That is why we believe that we cannot look the other way and that, in addition to demanding from Mauritania the freedom of Biram Dah Abeid, we must demand the abolition and end of slavery, as well as measures for states and the European Union to force multinationals to respect human rights around the world.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to point out, as has already been said here, that Mauritania was indeed the last state in the world to abolish the system of slavery in 1981. It was only after twenty-six years that she introduced the crime of slavery into her legislation. However, since 2007, only a few individual cases of convictions for the commission of this crime of slavery have been known. Yet, according to a report by The Walk Free Foundation, Mauritania is the country with the highest population living in modern-day slavery, at 4%. Both of these figures show how difficult and difficult it is to change ancient customs in traditionalist society, but this cannot constitute any excuse for this action.  The European Union, as a partner, should therefore help Mauritania to truly overcome this terrible situation. And I would like to thank Mr Preda for being the initiator of this, very important, resolution for me.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, curious country than Mauritania! It is worth recalling that the current Mauritanian President, Mohamed Ould Abdel Aziz, overthrew, in a military coup, the first and only truly democratically elected president since independence. Yet it is a country that is being spared. Although its president is credited with having rid the country of AQIM, Mauritania remains one of the hubs of trafficking in the region, which are among the main sources of financing for armed gangs of all kinds. Racism in this country wreaks havoc and is aimed primarily at African blacks. This racism remains institutionalized through slavery, which persists despite its official abolition in 1981 and its criminalization in 2007. To date, only one legal proceeding against a slave owner has been successful in seven years, that is to say. Since 2008, Biram Dah Abeid, a descendant of Haratin slaves but also a political opponent of the regime, has been leading the fight against these practices of another age, questioning, among other things, his religious justification. As such, he faces the death penalty. We must therefore put pressure on this country by all means to put an end to these practices and, despite its inadequacies, I will therefore vote for this resolution.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, once again we are here talking about Biram Dah Ould Abeid, a courageous activist tortured and imprisoned in Mauritania on 11 November for her fight against one of the greatest social scourges in this world. A scourge that offends the freedom of the poorest, children, the illiterate and those who are forced to serve a master so as not to live in hardship. Slavery, although banned in 1981, continues to be a systemic evil in a society that relies on unjustifiable forms of subordination that are difficult to sanction.  We have been sending money to this country for a long time. More than EUR 195 million has been transferred for social integration projects. Others come through the Development Fund. But in doing so, we are becoming accomplices of a government that has not yet understood that without respect for human rights there is no Cotonou, there is no State and there can be no friendship of Europe.  We therefore call on the High Representative not to close his eyes and to do everything in his power to ensure that Europe does not become a participant in those who, today, as in 2012, have imprisoned a man who is a symbol of an unequal struggle, to whom we must all join with strength and determination. Biram Dah Ould Abeid must be freed. All mauritanian people must be freed.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, it may be incredible, but in the 21st century more than 20% of Mauritania's population are slaves. Instead of trying to deal with this unacceptable situation, the country's government did something simpler: It arrested Mr. Abadi, the president of an anti-slavery activist organization, on unsubstantiated charges as well as some of the members of his organization. You will tell me that the mauritanian government's attitude may not be surprising, because it is undemocratic and we will condemn it. But when a government of a democratic country, such as the government of Greece, which, after the Prime Minister's brute intervention in justice, illegally detains the leader, MPs and officials of Greece's third-party political party, Golden Dawn, for 14 months illegally, why do we not show the same sensitivity? You are aware of this because two other members of my MePs have mentioned this on a number of occasions. But I mention it to show how much hypocrisy there is in this Chamber. If you think I'm wrong and I'm wrong, please disprove me.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Although slavery was abolished in Mauritania only in 1981, there are still no laws enforcing the ban. It is also worth highlighting the fact that in Mauritania it is hereditary and is associated with being born in this and not another ethnic group. The European Union cannot accept human rights violations, especially since this is happening in a country in the ACP group with which it cooperates.  However, the efforts of external states are often not enough to change the status quo. First of all, the work of local activists is essential, hence my support for the actions of Buram Dah Abeid and other people fighting slavery, who have been imprisoned many times. I call for the release of Buram Dah Abeid and other abolitionists, as well as for the government's real struggle in Nawaxzucie against the problem of slavery, because only action towards democracy and stability will enable a fruitful relationship between the European Union and Mauritania and to support the development of the country.

name: Seán KELLY
text: A Uachtaráin, seo an tríú bliain i ndiaidh a chéile go bhfuilimid ag caint faoi chearta daonna sa limistéar seo den domhan agus i ndáiríre is deacair a chreidiúint go bhfuilimid ag caint faoi sclábhaíocht sa lá atá inniu ann. Ach sin díreach mar atá, agus go háirithe nuair a thuigimid gurb í an Mháratáin an tír dheireanach ar domhan chun sclábhaíocht a chur ar ceal go hoifigiúil i mbliain 1981. Anois trí bliana is tríocha ina dhiaidh sin deirtear go bhfuil suas le 4 % nó níos mó, b’fhéidir suas le 20 % den daonra faoi sclábhaíocht.  Ní féidir cur suas leis seo agus caithfimid brú a chur ar an Máratáin cloí lena rialacha féin agus go háirithe seans a thabhairt do na sclábhaithe atá ag déanamh feirmeoireacht ar thalamh le cianta a bheith ina n-úinéirí ar an dtalamh sin agus freisin an fear iontach cróga Biram Dah Abeid a ligean saor. Níl aon chúis go bhfuil sé i bpríosún in aon chor.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Biram Dah Abeid is the leader of the Initiative to Abolish Slavery, which brings together some 9,000 activists. In 2013, he was awarded the United Nations Human Rights Prize for his work. Unfortunately, on November 11, Biram Dah Abeid, along with 16 activists of his movement after a peaceful march for the abolition of slavery, was convicted and imprisoned. We call for their immediate release. Mauritania is a partner country of the European Union under the ACP Association Agreement. We would therefore like to remind you that the European Union is against slavery, child labour, their mutilation and any other form of restriction on civil liberties. We demand that the Government of Mauritania respect its international commitments and implement appropriate legislation to protect its own citizens. The European Commission and the European External Action Service should strengthen their relations with the Mauritanian authorities in order to continue the mission of the activists there to protect human rights and effectively fight against the various forms of slavery.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Indeed, here we have a resolution primarily on the protection of human rights, without political purposes such as the previous resolution concerning Venezuela. Slavery is a generalised regime in Mauritania and prosecutions against human rights activists and Biram Dah Abeid must be stopped. I therefore condemn the slavery that exists in Mauritania. I support the resolution, and the European Parliament is right to deal with the protection of human rights. But it must do the same for the violation of human rights in the European Union itself, in the countries under a memorandum; countries where the Troika is brutally violating human rights. In fact, we have come to the point where the Commission says, in response to a question, that it cannot respect human rights in the case of Greece because that is where the memorandum applies. It is unacceptable and we condemn it. (Applause)

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Mr. President, is it possible that today in this Parliament we are discussing a country that is actually our partner and that practices slavery?  Mauretania, colleagues and colleagues, is a member of the Union for the Mediterranean, a member, therefore, of a union that we have launched in the European Union. In this context, I want to express my strong support for this resolution clearly, I want to say very clearly that I expect High Commissioner Mogherini to do everything to free Mr. Abeid from prison in Mauretania because it has become a symbol of the fight against one system, but above all against the inhumane conditions in which almost 20% of the population of Mauretania lives. That's why I expect decisive action from Mrs Mogherini.

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we welcome the European Parliament's urgent resolution on the human rights situation in Mauritania, which closely touches on the case of Biram Dah Abei and other members of his organisation, the IRA. We are well aware of the case of Biram, a Mauritanian human rights defender and anti-slavery activist, who was arrested several times for his convictions and actions and accused of apostasy in 2012. Biram is the president of the IRA, the Initiative for the Rebirth of the Abolitionist Anti-Slavery Movement, an activity that has earned him numerous international tributes in the field of human rights. As a politician, he also ran in the last presidential elections last June. Biram was arrested along with other IRA members at an unauthorized rally, on charges of disturbing public order, insulting the authorities and belonging to an unregnized organisation. According to his organization, the rally served to denounce the lack of respect for the traditional land rights of Mauritanians, mostly black, in the south of the country, near the border with Senegal. At the same time, the Mauritanian authorities declare that Biram is now in the hands of the judges, who are the subject of legal proceedings. We are very concerned about these latest arrests. Through our delegation in Mauritania, we are in regular contact with biram's organisation, we are informed of his situation in prison and of the progress of judicial proceedings. We take every opportunity to engage with the authorities on this issue. Eu ropean Union ambassadors to Mauritania raised biram's case with the Prime Minister immediately after his arrest and further discussions on the matter took place on 15 December as part of the political dialogue provided for in the Cotonou Agreement. On that occasion, the European Union reiterated the need to fully respect biram's rule of law and rights and stressed that equality and non-discrimination for all ethnic and racial communities are fundamental factors for the unity and stability of the country. The European Union will continue to follow the case of Biram Dah Abei very closely. we will also continue to engage in dialogue with the authorities and civil society to ensure that it is treated fairly and impartially. If the development of the situation so requires, we will not hesitate to take further action. We have been informed that the process could take place as early as today. The Eu ropean Union delegation on the ground is following developments and will follow the process closely, which should in any case take place as soon as possible. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union has entered into a regular dialogue with Mauritania on the issue of human rights. We are also supporting the government in its efforts to strengthen institutions and harmonise legislation with human rights standards, but more needs to be done. In March 2014 Mauritania adopted a road map promoted by the United Nations with a series of recommendations to eradicate slavery to the last forms. It also agreed to set up a special criminal court to deal with cases of slavery.  The European Union is strongly encouraging the government to continue the implementation of the road map. We are in close contact with the UN Human Rights Office in this respect. We also organise regular meetings with human rights defenders, which will allow us to have a more complete view of the situation and to understand how they see the government's efforts and, in this regard, we would point out that the European Union also funds three projects under the human rights and democracy programme in Mauritania which benefits local NGOs. The case of Biram, however, reminds us that much more progress still needs to be made.  I can assure you that in the context of our dialogue and cooperation with Mauritania, the issue of human rights, including the problems of slavery and existing practices and the case of Biram Dah Abei and other cases that may arise in the future, will remain at the top of our agendas and will continue to be a priority of our diplomatic action.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place after the debates. Written statements (Article 162 of the Regulation)

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: in writing. With this resolution, Parliament is once again showing its commitment to the protection of human rights and democracy. We deplore all forms of slavery, violence, the restriction of individual freedoms and racial discrimination and strongly believe in dialogue with the Mauritanian authorities in order to contribute to democracy, stability and the development of the country. Mauritania is a strategic partner within the framework of the EU's Security and Development Strategy in the Sahel and an important partner for pursuing clear and workable human rights policies, in line with the EU's strategic framework on human rights and democracy. In this regard, I call for the creation of European Parliament observer missions to the political, administrative and judicial authorities of the Mauritanian Government, with the task of restoring the progress that the country is making towards the process of democracy and the protection of human rights.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The next item is the debate on seven proposals for a Resolution on Sudan: the case of Amin Mekki Medani [(2014/3000(RSP)].

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: Author. Mr President, we are calling for attention today for three human rights activists in Sudan: Mr Amin Mekki Medani, Mr Farouk Abu Eissa, Mr Farah Ibrahim Mohammed Alagar. We were also here for the summer holidays to call attention to a woman in prison with a child in Sudan. We can keep doing this over and over again. What we know for sure is that the regime in Sudan has no respect for human rights.  Mr. Amin Mekki Medani was arrested in Khartoum, the capital of Sudan, after returning from an activity abroad. There, he had signed a resolution calling for democracy in Sudan to ensure that the opposition unites for elections in the spring. The same opposition has already said that the elections in the spring, in April 2015, cannot be trusted in this way. I find it very difficult to see how things are going wrong over and over again in a country like Sudan and how the incentives that are coming are being suppressed by the government.  Last night we discussed the Khartoum process, a process in which the European Member States have reached an agreement with the North African countries to keep migrants in Africa. That agreement was concluded, among other things, with Sudan. It seems to me, in the light of the arrest of these three human rights defenders, a terrible shame that we are getting involved with a country like Sudan and thus putting their people in an even more dangerous situation simply because they are no longer able to flee.

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: Author. - (DE) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for the excellent work he has It was only in May of this year that the international public was alarmed by the death sentence against the Sudanese Christian Maryam Yahya Ibrahim Ishaq, who was to be executed for her faith. The immediate international protest had led to her being freed and able to leave Sudan. Now we need our urgent help and attention from Dr. Amin Mekki Medani, a proven human rights activist in his country, Sudan, who was arrested and detained by the Sudanese secret service on 6 December for signing the Sudan Call. In the Sudan Call, representatives of various Sudanpolitical groups are calling for an end to the resurgent fighting and human rights violations in various regions of Sudan and for a peace and reconciliation process to be initiated in the run-up to the elections. We call for the immediate release of Dr Amin Mekki Medani, who is already 76 years old and dependent on the constant use of medicines, which he is denied by the Sudanese security forces. This is life-threatening for him. We call on the leaders of Sudan to finally launch a peace process and to respect civil and human rights in their country.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: author. - Mr President, the ECR Group calls for the Sudanese authorities to release Dr Amin Mekki Medani immediately. His arrest was not only arbitrary but his detention is considered a reprisal in order to sanction and stop his legitimate human rights activities.  Following his arrest shortly after he returned from Addis, serious concerns were raised for his safety. He is 76 years old, suffers from high blood pressure and diabetes and has been denied the right to take his medication by the security services. The Sudanese authorities, led by the indicted war criminal President Omar al-Bashir, have acted deplorably in this case.  Furthermore, in addition for calling for Dr Medani’s immediate release, my Group urges the authorities to put an end to all acts of harassment and intimidation against human rights defenders in general and, lastly, to comply with the UN Declaration on Human Rights Defenders and all regional and international human rights instruments ratified by Sudan.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Author. - (DE) Mr President, I would like to thank For the third time in a short space of time, we are dealing with the human rights situation in the region. We always hear that it may be in the interests of stability to suspend human rights. This is a perverse and dangerous view of things. Stability can only be established if the rule of law prevails and human rights are upheld, as provided for in the Sudan Call, which was signed by a wide range of groups at the beginning of December. Also present was Dr. Amin Mekki Medani, a highly respected former politician and human rights activist.  We call for the immediate release of Dr Medani and we call on Sudan to finally seek dialogue with the country's constructive forces.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Author. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, have you heard of Sudan Call? An appeal for the end of the single party in Sudan and a collection of signatures for a transitional government in that country. The ink of sudan call's appeal came to an end when the Sudanese Government's National Intelligence and Security Service began arresting the signatories. Among the signatories are Amin Mekki Madani, a lawyer and human rights defender, and Farouk Abu Issa, leader of the opposition: people arrested only because they decided to oppose a government and express a different voice. So, in Sudan, there is systematic violence against anyone who decides to carry out any peaceful resistance movement. These people are courageous people that we must try to defend, and the resolution is aimed at that. Let us try to approve it.

name: Urmas PAET
text: author. - Mr President, the situation in Sudan still needs our urgent attention. There are constant reports of the killing and torture of people, harassment of political activists and human rights defenders, as well as cases of Sudanese government soldiers using sexual violence, including gang rape of teenage girls, as a weapon of war against the rebels. The Sudanese authorities must stop their harassment and must comply with the relevant international norms and standards, in particular the UN Declaration on Human Rights Defenders of 1998, and all regional and international human rights instruments also ratified by Sudan.  The recent case of the arrest of Dr Amin Mekki Medani is another example of what is wrong in Sudan. He must be released immediately. The ICC Prosecutor already presented, years ago, evidence showing that Sudanese President al-Bashir committed crimes of genocide, crimes against humanity and war crimes, but al-Bashir is still president, he is still free and crimes continue. The UN and ICC must finally implement what has been decided, to stop the violations of human rights in Sudan and harassment against human rights defenders.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: Author. Mr President, I am one of those who last night denounced the Khartoum process which legitimises the dictators of the Horn of Africa. This is especially true for Sudan, where the sinister al-Bashir has been raging since 1989. Yet his days could be numbered. The opposition has never gathered so widely and this is what explains the behaviour of the Sudanese authorities: the announcement of the election, the defeat of the Addis Ababa agreements, the resumption of bombing of the civilian population and increased repression of all kinds, especially against Amin Mekki Medani and Farah Mohamed Ibrahim Alagar, which is highly symbolic, since they are signatories to the call for Sudan. The shortcomings of the international community in the face of this unprecedented situation, including in the UN Security Council, unable to condemn UNAMID's abuses, are unforgivable. We must not only call for the release of all political prisoners, but also support the Sudanese opposition in its call for the implementation of a dialogue process that will finally enable the Sudanese people, not dictators who oppress them, to live in peace.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, the truth is that I had never had the feeling of speaking in a public square like I am right now. I will not spend my time summarizing the facts because they have already been widely exposed. Amin Mekki Medani is a man, he seems to be, very dangerous: 76 years old; He suffers from medical problems, but has been arrested along with others and others for wanting a better future for his people, for wanting that future peacefully, for wanting that future from democratic values, for wanting that future from the citizen values that we, from the European Union, share because they are also our values. It is very dangerous, it seems, to commit to work to achieve the end of conflicts that hit the different regions of Sudan, and in the necessary legal, institutional and economic reforms. Sudan is in a critical period when political dialogue is very fragile, so Mr Medani's figure is now more necessary than ever. The European Union should urge the Government of Sudan, as this Resolution does, to ensure the peaceful exercise of freedoms of expression, association and assembly, human rights, as well as the immediate release of Mr Medani and the rest of the activists.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the winds of war in Sudan have not subsided. To date, human rights violations across the country are documented by various human rights organisations. The massacres in the Darfur region, the bombing of the people of South Kordofan and the incursions against civilians in the Blue Nile region are all events that bear witness to these violations of human rights. In addition, there is the abuse of voices and dissent in Khartoum and of those who denounce these violations. This is the case of Amin Mekki Medani, one of these voices. Arrested a few days ago at the age of 76, he is being arbitrarily detained by Sudanese security agents. With this resolution, Mr President, we are strongly calling for an inclusive peace dialogue that will take the country towards a complete democracy and a rule of law. Without a serious internal peace process in Sudan, the whole area of the Horn of Africa is in danger of seeing any attempt at stabilisation fail, with inevitable consequences also on migratory flows and towards the South. The liberation of Medani is the first step towards peace, dialogue and an end to violations.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – The political, social situation in Sudan is becoming increasingly unstable. This country reached a critical point in its history when public authorities began to use highly repressive police methods. Their aim is to restrict freedom of expression and speech. The aim is also to ban free political debate. This activity is illegal. This violates the norms and standards of international law. As a member of the Committee on Civil Liberties, I would like to draw attention to the worrying event of the arrest of Dr Medani, a human rights defender. In order to protect the fundamental rights of the Sudanese people, the European Union must react strongly. Attention should also be paid to persecution of faith. Freedom of faith must be guaranteed, which must not be the cause of persecution. Let us send a clear signal, let us not allow silence during open discrimination.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, many things could be said about Sudan and they are almost all painful. We could talk about the humanitarian situation in Darfur, a persistent crisis far from being resolved, or about the fact that the International Criminal Court has just suspended proceedings for war crimes committed in the region and, consequently, on President Omar Hassan al-Bashir, noting with bitterness the lack of UN initiative in this regard and therefore the waste of resources in keeping this process open. I would therefore like to confine myself at this minute to making an appeal. An appeal for Dr. Medani, a human rights defender, an activist, a brave but elderly and sick man, unceremoniously arrested for participating in an initiative called Sudan Call aimed only at helping his people out of dictatorship. An appeal to all the others who, for the same reason, have been imprisoned, for the representatives of the opposition, for journalists and for all those who have paid a heavy price for the desire for freedom and democracy, just on the eve of new farce elections. Free them! I say this to the Sudanese Government and to the entire international community. Free them! Because a country that arrests its children is a country that arrests and kills its future.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on 6 December, Dr Medani, a lawyer and human rights activist, was arrested by the Sudanese security services. This case shows, once again, that Sudan, in the grip of a bloody civil war, is being repressed against all forms of freedom, whether it is freedom of expression , in the case of Dr. Medani, or religious freedom, since you know, ladies and gentlemen, Christians are widely persecuted in this country. We remember, for our part, the fate of Meriam, a Christian woman sentenced to death for apostasy by a court in Khartoum. However, the resolution proposed to us is not acceptable as it stands. It is a model of the will to be totally interfering and, I would even say, almost Western arrogance. I repeat: if we condemn ill-treatment, we are not here to dictate to people the nature of the political regimes they must establish. Therefore, our position will be abstention, because to vote for this resolution would be to condone interference, while voting against would be tantamount to sitting down on the crime.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Once again in the European Parliament, we are discussing the persecution of human rights defenders by the security services in Sudan. On December 6, 76-year-old Dr. Amin Meki Medani, a well-known activist and promoter of the rule of law, was arrested. The detention was in response to his signed declaration on the "establishment of a civil state and democracy", in which signatories, mainly from opposition parties, including the Sudanese Revolutionary Front, call for an end to armed conflicts in various regions of Sudan, calling for legal, institutional and economic reforms. We strongly condemn the illegal detention in custody of the seriously ill and deprived of access to Dr Medani's medicines. We call for his immediate release, as well as all other political prisoners. In the light of the repression that is r spreading in the country, we expect the Sudanese authorities to put an end to illegal detention and to fulfil their obligations under the United Nations Declaration on guaranteeing fundamental civil liberties, including freedom of expression, assembly and religion.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Mr. President! As we have already heard today, Dr Medani was arrested by Sudanese authorities at the beginning of December. As far as I know, the reason is not yet fully understood, probably because he signed the Sudan Call. This is an initiative that seeks to introduce peace and democracy in Sudan. I think it is particularly tragic to arrest a 76-year-old man for advocating democracy. However, we do not need to look so far, in Sudan, because on 14 December this year 31 people were arrested in Turkey, many of them journalists. I think that Turkey's approach is particularly noteworthy when one considers that the European taxpayer pays EUR 1 billion a year – I repeat: EUR 1 billion a year – to Turkey as pre-accession aid, a total of EUR 4.9 billion since 2007. However, there is no added value from these payments. On the contrary, it seems that Turkey is moving further and further away from our values.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: I would like to welcome the delegation of the Swiss Parliament, headed by Kathy Riklin, and which has the presence of the Vice-Chairmen of the Committee on Foreign Affairs of the National Council, Roland Rino Bochel, and the Committee on Foreign Affairs of the Council of States, Christian Levrat. The Swiss delegation participated this morning in the thirty-third inter-parliamentary meeting of the European Union-Switzerland and also had an excellent discussion with its partners in the European Parliament. Needless to say, we hope that all this will help to resolve the current divergences between the European Union and Switzerland.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: We resumed the debate on seven proposals for a Resolution on Sudan: the case of Amin Mekki Medani [(2014/3000(RSP)] .

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we welcome the European Parliament's initiative for an urgent resolution on the case of Amin Mekki Medani, the President of the Confederation of Sudanese Civil Society Organisations. Arrested, as has been mentioned several times during the debate, by the Sudanese security forces on 6 December 2014, Amin Mekki Medani has since been detained in solitary confinement and his arrest is part of the government's campaign against the so-called Sudan Call, the call for peace and democratic change that Amin Mekki Medani signed, as a representative of Sudanese civil society groups , on 3 December in Addis Ababa, together with other leaders of the main opposition parties and rebel movements. Amin Mekki Medani is for us a person of great moral stature who tirelessly fights, as a leading lawyer and civil society activist, in defence of human rights in Sudan and internationally. In 2013, the European Union delegation awarded him the Human Rights Prize and involved him assiduously in his activities. We call on the Sudanese Government to release him and the other political prisoners immediately. The head of the Eu ropean Union delegation in Khartoum, who maintains contact with family members, is discussing his case with the highest echelons. The arrest and imprisonment of Amin Mekki Medani is not only en route to Sudanese law and the Sudanese constitution, it is a flagrant violation of freedom of expression. A violation that also conflicts with the objectives and principles of the national dialogue, announced by the government in early 2014. It is clear that such a public debate on the state's bases and policies will not succeed without a climate of freedom of expression for citizens and until the weapons are laid down. This is what the EU's foreign ministers expect, as is apparent from the conclusions of 20 October. The human rights situation in Sudan continues to give rise to deep concern: arbitrary arrests, intimidation, ill-treatment of political activists, human rights defenders and journalists severely restrict the political space. The media are under control and censorship, while the conflicts in Darfur, south Kordofan and the Blue Nile region continue to inflict deep trauma and suffering, with indiscriminate air strikes, scorched earth, mass displacement, widespread violence against women and children and a ban on humanitarian access, all with complete impunity. We call for an end to these conflicts and we find it worrying that the peace talks conducted by the African Union group under the aegis of President Mbeki were suspended last week to no avail. I would like to assure you that human rights and peace will continue to be our main concern in all contacts with Sudanese actors. Mr President, I would like to thank you for your attention and I would like to take this opportunity, on behalf of the Italian Presidency, to wish you and all members a happy new year.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: Thank you very much, Mr Della Vedova. We thank you for your commitment since the Italian Presidency to the European Union The debate is closed. The vote takes place below.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Mr. Speaker, my motion of order is based on section 166 of the regulation. We defend freedom of expression, and that is fine. Having expressed, in the corridors of this Parliament, my disagreement with a hideous painting, which at this time of Christmas degrades the image of Christ and his mother, I am being sued by the President of Parliament, who asks me for an explanation for the sanctions that my attitude deserves. Since the majority group in Parliament claims Christian democracy, let it at least express what it thinks of this degrading image!
