name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: Mr Gollnisch, we do not intend to close anyone's freedom of expression, but this is a matter which is in the hands of the Quaestors. Then less populism and less opportunism. (Various reactions) Written statements (Article 162 of the Regulation)

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. – As a long-standing member of Amnesty International and as a member of this Parliament's Human Rights Committee, it strikes me that human rights violations are on the rise, particularly in Islamic countries. Yes, it is true that the death penalty also exists in 24 STATES in the United States, but it has been abolished in most Western countries. On the other hand, they exist in most Islamic countries. Yes, it is true, there are still massive restrictions on human rights all over the world, but why are they particularly registered in Islamic countries? Why do more than 50% of people, girls and women, have their human rights in place? In Nigeria and Iran, actual and alleged adulterers are stoned, in Saudi Arabia women are not allowed to drive, in many Islamic countries the genitals of girls are mutilated, girls are not trained as well as boys, there are forced marriages. When is there an unbiased discussion about the increase in human rights violations and the absence of press freedom and democracy in 55 out of 57 Islamic countries? What are we doing to give more influence to enlightened Muslims, not only in Lebanon and Tunisia, but in all Islamic countries?

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: in writing. – The human rights violations currently occurring in Sudan are reprehensible and must be dealt with urgently. The unjust arrest of Dr Medani is only one among the latest incidents in a long history of abuses by the Sudanese Government. Over the past year, Human Rights Watch reported serious violations of international humanitarian and human rights law; Sudanese security forces continue to arrest and detain activists, opposition party members, and people suspected of links to rebel groups. I echo this resolution’s call to strongly denounce the arbitrary arrest and detention of Dr Medani and to consider it as a reprisal to sanction his legitimate human rights activities. I want to stress the importance of the recent signed Agreements on the National Dialogue and Constitutional Process as being instruments in making progress towards national peace, reconciliation and democratic governance in Sudan. Thus, I strongly urge the Commission, the Member States and all the international stakeholders to support this initiative and the Sudanese people in their transition to an internally reformed democracy and to make all the necessary efforts for the release of Dr Medani.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. – I ask the Sudanese Government to release Dr. Amin Mekki Medani from prison, as well as other human rights activists who were arrested for expressing their displeasment against the Sudanese government. The Sudanese government should start respecting the international conventions it has signed.  Mr. Medani's health is severely impaired, they don't give him medication, and he's 76. His human rights are being violated because he signed an initiative aimed at ending the conflict in Sudan, establishing social and economic reforms and establishing a legal state.  The political and social situation in Sudan is highly unstable, and the media is subject to censorship. Authorities use unlawful mechanisms to limit the freedoms of all those who think differently. The question of a different opinion, and in particular the question of faith cannot be the basis for any persecution, and this is happening in Sudan especially when it comes to Christians against which I raise my voice.  The European Union must force the Sudanese government to release Mr. Medani and to start respecting the freedom of thought, freedom of religion and human rights of its citizens.

name: Tadeusz ZWIEFKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Once again, the European Parliament, in its resolution, draws public attention to Sudan. This African country, mired in the chaos of hostilities and on the brink of a humanitarian catastrophe, is increasingly being distanced from any international standards of respect for human rights. The unjustified arrest of Dr Medani, a widely respected human rights defender, is a glaring manifestation of this. Looking at the situation in Sudan, one can get the impression that the sudanese authorities are working towards the destruction of the state and society. The restrictions placed on NGOs seeking to provide humanitarian aid to sudanese citizens in a dramatic situation show that the sudanese authorities have the lives of their own citizens for nothing. This country in the heart of Africa is becoming a black spot on the world map, and if the international community does not make effective, peaceful attempts to resolve the conflicts in these areas, it may soon turn out that the situation in Sudan will destabilise the entire region. While calling for Dr Medani's unconditional release, we call on the Sudanese authorities to remember and change their attitude towards the organisations and individuals who wish to provide assistance to the most deprived in the country.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: João FERREIRA
text: Madam President, the services have at the last few sessions refused to accept explanations of vote on the urgencies, on the grounds that the Rules of Procedure do not provide for it. It is not acceptable, however, in a vote like this, which also has several roll-be votes, members cannot express themselves by means of a explanation of vote on the reasons for their vote. I think it's something that should lead us all to reflect on this... this rule should not be justified and therefore explanations of vote should be allowed to be made.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: As you have just said, this is a rule in the Rules of Procedure and we take note of your objection.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: Before moving to the next item on our agenda, allow me to welcome in the official gallery the President of Georgia, Giorgi Margvelashvili, who has come to Strasbourg to witness the historic vote of the consent on the EU-Georgia Association agreement. (Applause) On behalf of the European Parliament, a warm welcome to you and congratulations to the Georgian people on this remarkable achievement.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: We now continue with the vote.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: author. - Madam President, I would like to move an oral amendment, but, first of all, let me welcome the former President of Georgia, Mikheil Saakashvili, who is also here. (Applause and jeers) I would like to move an oral amendment for a new paragraph 16, to read as follows: ‘Welcomes the OSCE/ODIHR “Trial Monitoring Report Georgia” issued on 9 December 2014 and calls on the Georgian Government to seriously undertake efforts to meet the shortcomings identified therein.’

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the problems that are currently raising migratory flows from the Mediterranean can be addressed more effectively by a holistic approach by the European Union to this phenomenon. There are ambitious but necessary objectives to be achieved, with actions to prevent further tragedies in the Mediterranean, to rethink the modalities of legal access routes, to dismantle criminal groups that profit from the despair of migrants, to respect human rights and human dignity, to revise European legislation in this area – in particular the Dublin Regulation – to have a rapid review of migrants' requests , to have strict controls on how money is spent on immigration and asylum.  The latter is a fundamental aspect: an investigation is under way in Italy concerning speculation on funds relating to the reception system. A disturbing interweaving of political circles and organised crime has been revealed. The focus on controls must never fail. The hope is that the European Union will start a debate as soon as possible in order to reshap its immigration policies. I therefore support the motion for a resolution.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The refugee situation around the Mediterranean is getting worse and worse. The Islamic State's war in Syria and Iraq, as well as the fragile political and economic situation in North Africa, are forcing more and more people to flee to Europe.  Above all, I follow the situation in Syria very closely as a member of the Mashreq delegation. We must help these people, especially on the ground, but also those who are already in Europe.  What is important is that all EU Member States must support each other in this process according to their performance, as provided for in Article 80 of the EU Treaty. The distribution of refugee flows must be fair, otherwise we will overwhelm the population in our Member States. I call on the Commission to take this into account when it takes its refugee policy and to take appropriate measures to this end.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I supported the resolution because it is a further small but important step towards keeping a high level of guard on an issue, that of immigration, which we can no longer allow ourselves to hypocritically call an emergency. An emergency that becomes routine is clearly a hypocritical contradiction; So let us not miss an opportunity, as early as tomorrow, to force ourselves every day to demand loud and clear everything that still remains to be done. Immediately clarify Triton, to immediately define the future, because the heroism and efforts that Italy and the Italians have supported with Mare Nostrum are not in vain. The distribution of responsibilities must be absolutely fair and Frontex must have a representative seat in Italy, for example in Sicily, or at any case in a Mediterranean country that is an outpost of flows. It is indefensible to find new channels of legal migration. There is an urgent need for the possibility of obtaining status already in the country of origin so as to prevent further tragedies.

name: Jordi Vicent SEBASTIA TALAVERA
text: Madam President, we voted in favour of this resolution because we are living very dramatically the drama of migrants trying to reach Europe through the Mediterranean. I come from the Valenci Country, on the shores of the Mediterranean, and in the coalition I represent there are colleagues from Andalusia, from the Balearic Islands and also from Ceuta and Melilla, where this drama is lived every day. We like the Resolution because it recognizes the need to give a global approach to the issue of immigration. Not the immigration problem, the immigration issue. We like it, because it assumes responsibility for the European Union for its policy in those countries from which this immigration originates and also because it stresses the need to examine our policy of cooperation. Because only a policy of cooperation that really supports the countries from which these poor people come trying to improve their quality of life, that actually develops future possibilities in those countries will prevent the flow of this bleeding immigration from continuing.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, like my colleagues on the National Front, I voted against this resolution, which does not address the fundamental problem of mass immigration that is affecting our countries in Europe. Is the European Union capable of controlling the 48,000 kilometres of coastline and 9,400 kilometres of external land borders of its 28 Member States, if at all? The answer, of course, is no. Since the Schengen Agreements came into force, the European Union has failed in everything it has done to control external borders. Hordes of illegal immigrants pour into the southern eu states before spreading to other Member States, including France. Every week, nearly a thousand illegal immigrants cross the French-Italian border, near Nice, where I am elected. It is time to draw the conclusions of this failure and immediately suspend the Schengen agreements in order to restore state control of their borders.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: Madam President! I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the situation in the Mediterranean and the EU's holistic approach to migration. A holistic approach to migration is the only right way to respond to the challenge that the European Union is currently facing with regard to immigration. Migration flows are a structural problem within the European Union. The control of external borders and asylum policy have a major impact on the human rights of emigrants, and the situation in the Mediterranean reminds us of this every day. We therefore urgently need to launch a new strategy for legal migration. In this context, I recommend that consideration be given to the Austrian Government's proposal for distribution, which is based on a principle of solidarity.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, there is now a widespread awareness that, in order to tackle migration-related problems, coordinated action is needed on many aspects. The main causes of migration, wars, poverty and persecution must be prevented and combated in the countries of origin. In the short term, everything must be done to save the lives of those who are forced to embark on extremely dangerous journeys, which are, moreover, being exploited by criminal organisations. Alternative and legal channels need to be developed in order to reach Europe and we need a more efficient and integrated asylum and reception system. These and other measures are referred to in the resolution we have voted on, which, although it cannot be considered, nor does it intend to set itself, as a complete and comprehensive response, is nevertheless a useful step, perhaps the most useful that this Parliament can take, precisely in order to facilitate and bring the adoption of this measure closer together, identifying certain priorities for intervention and urging the States, the Commission and its own internal articulations to move along the path mapped out. That is why I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Madam President, I would just like to make one very important observation on this issue. In October 2013, the European Parliament adopted a resolution on immigration in the Mediterranean. Shortly thereafter, the Council set up a Task Force on the Mediterranean, followed by several Commission communications. I very much welcome this resolution, because it is complex in many respects. I personally support a comprehensive solution agreed by all the States of the European Union. And my last wish for 2015 is that we really look for a solution that we, the democratic parties of the European Parliament, can agree on. If we Democrats do not talk about immigration, we will leave this issue to various populists and nationalists, and that will certainly not benefit the subject of immigration. Thank you and i wish you a happy holiday.

name: Alessandra MORETTI
text: Madam President, I welcome today's vote. The absence of an integrated immigration policy is no longer acceptable. It is becoming more and more evident every day, unfortunately after every tragedy at sea, the need to develop a global approach to migration, in which all The Member States collectively take responsibility for these sad events, showing solidarity and commitment. We need concrete, decisive responses, first and foremost on the causes and not just on the effects, responses that propose to find new channels of legal migration and that develop a strategy of cooperation with third countries. The Mediterranean, our sea, has converted into a cemetery, a mass grave of unidentified corpses. This situation needs urgent responses and everyone's awareness that the border countries are no longer able to manage this situation on their own.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — This proposal for a Resolution by Parliament calls for the generalised system of preferences not to be granted until the Philippines ends illegal fishing, child trafficking, etc. The EU grants the GSP+ system to third countries on the condition that they ratify and respect 27 international conventions, some of which the Philippines is not respecting.  I voted in favour of Parliament's motion for a resolution as it calls for the GSP+ system not to be granted until guarantees are given by the Philippines.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution, which aims to prevent the Philippines from granting GSP+ status until the Commission has abolished the yellow card granted to them for illegal fishing. The Commission granted them this card after it found that the Philippines was not complying with the rules on combating illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. Allowing the Philippines to join the GSP+ would mean allowing fishery products from the Philippines to EU markets without any duty and without guaranteeing that those products come from legitimate fishing. I support the proposal to await the Commission's decision to withdraw the yellow card granted to them before granting the Philippines GSP+ status. This resolution sends a message to EU citizens and fishermen: we cannot accept that the EU faces unfair competition from illegal products.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the amendments tabled by the GUE/NGL Group and the Alternative Resolution I have signed on granting the application of the tariff preference system to the Philippines, as the Philippines has received a 'yellow card' from the European Commission in relation to illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing. I agree that the Philippines should not be granted GSP+ status until the Commission cancels its notification to the Philippines as a third country likely to be considered non-cooperative in the fight against IDNR fishing.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The purpose of this motion for a resolution is to object to the granting of GSP tariff preferences to the Philippines.  The EU's Generalised Tariff Preference System (GSP) proposes tariff reductions or duty-free access to the EU market for exports from 178 developing countries and territories.  For example, for competing imports of canned tuna, granting the Philippines GSP tariff preferences would increase tariffs to 0%, from the current 24%. This will fuel increased unfair competition at the expense of European fishermen already hard hit by the Commission's fussy regulations, even though the country has not yet demonstrated that it is complying with all the conventions required to benefit from the GSP. In addition, the Philippines is under investigation for illegal, undeclared, unregistered fishing (ININ fishing). That is why I voted for this text.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. — (SV) I have voted against granting the Philippines GSP+ status. The trade agreement requires respect for human rights. On 4 December this year, Amnesty International presented the report 'Above the Law: Torture in the Philippines' which clarifies a culture of impunity that allows police in the Philippines to continue with torture unhindered. Amnesty has launched a major campaign in the country to stop torture. In other words, it is clear that the Philippines does not respect human rights. Europe must take a consistent approach to these issues. In addition, the agreement includes a fisheries policy which involves a major overexploitation of Philippine fishing grounds, as they do not comply with international regulations in this area. Parties to trade agreements must respect their human rights commitments and a sustainable and consistent fisheries policy.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. — This motion for a resolution is intended to object to the granting of GSP tariff preferences to the Philippines. The EU's generalised tariff preference system (GSP) allows tariff reductions or duty-free access to the EU market for exports from 178 developing countries and territories. For example, for competing imports of canned tuna, granting the Philippines GSP tariff preferences would increase tariffs to 0%, from the current 24%. Such a measure could effectively amplify the unfair competition already faced by European fishermen. European fishermen already subject to abusive and very restrictive regulations. In addition, the Philippines has not yet provided guarantees of compliance with the conventions required to benefit from the GSP. Finally, the country must respond to an investigation into illegal, undeclared, unregistered fishing (INT fishing). In view of these different elements, I voted for this text.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. - I supported the postponement of the GSP+ concession to the Philippines in the light of the reports being made to consider the Philippines as a non-cooperative country on illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing, and the impact that the granting of this preferential access system would have on the competitiveness and future viability of the EU tuna processing and canning industry and , in particular Galicia, Europe's first fishing region. On 4 December, Amnesty International denounced the continued use of torture and abuse by law enforcement – which goes against GSP+ requirements – despite the country's efforts to combat it. The report details vexing and torture practices and the impunity enjoyed by those who commit them. It estimates almost half a thousand cases since 2001, 75 in the last year (2013), although the country's Human Rights Commission recognizes that the number of un reported cases would actually be much higher. I call for no decisions to be taken rashly and without all the guarantees, preventing European industry from competing on an equal footing.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. "My colleague Franck Proust and I have brought to the attention of this House the problem of illegal fishing in the Philippines through a resolution rejecting that country's access to the generalised preference system SGP. It is inappropriate to grant a preferential tariff at zero tariffs in the Philippines when it is impossible to trace the legal origin of certain products. I voted in favour of this resolution and I am saddened to see that it was not adopted by a qualified majority of Members of Parliament. However, I will continue to fight for consistency in European policies. We cannot both fight illegal fishing and offer privileges to a country that does not comply with European standards in this area.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — The Regulation on the special incentive scheme for sustainable development and good governance (GSP+), in which the Republic of the Philippines has requested participation, sets out the obligation of third countries to achieve the objectives adopted by regional fisheries organisations, one of which is the fight against illegal, undeclared and unregulated (INTA) fishing. I voted today in favour of this resolution, which does not grant GSP+ status to the Philippines, because the Republic of the Philippines is considered a third country that is not cooperating in the fight against illegal fishing. I think it is essential to insist on the absolute need to ensure the coherence and credibility of European policies, in order to avoid discrimination and unfair competition for European fishermen and to protect European consumers. The issue of illegal fishing is a matter for any country and we cannot create precedents. If we want to ask our fishermen about sustainability, we cannot close our eyes to other countries, such as the Philippines, which are not complying with the rules.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. - I voted against this resolution as I oppose the politicisation of trade. I believe that genuine free trade is the only way to bring the third world out of poverty, and support the concept of ‘Trade, Not Aid’.

name: Jean-Marie CAVADA
text: In writing. I voted against this commission delegated act because I do not think we should agree to bring in products at preferential rates that could be from undeclared and unregolopped fishing. This would lead to unfair competition for European producers and send an incomprehensible message to the Philippine authorities and to all developing states.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. — The main objective of the GSP is to facilitate access for developing countries and territories to the EU market by reducing customs duties on their goods. Following the request made by the Philippines to the special scheme to encourage sustainable development and good governance, known as gSP+, duty-free is intended for approximately 66 % of the total tariff positions provided for in the normal GSP. As this special regime is conditional on the implementation of ratification by countries of relevant international conventions on sustainable development, I do not seem to be fulfilled by the Philippines with the conditions for accessing this special regime. I am not only referring to the issue of illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing by this State, but above all to the conclusions of the UN Report on Trafficking in Human Beings, which notes the existence of human trafficking, especially in women and children, for the purposes of labour exploitation in the agriculture, fisheries, construction, manufacturing and services sectors. For these reasons I refuse to grant GSP+ status to the Philippines.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of this resolution on the application of a generalised system of tariff preferences for the Philippines. Indeed, I agree with the objections raised to the Commission's delegated regulation, particularly in relation to human rights violations in that country, as is apparent from the report by the UN special rapporteur, in particular on trafficking in human rights. Furthermore, I agree with the assessment that the concept of marketing state liability must be developed more fully as a means of closing markets to INTA fishery products.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — The livelihoods of European fishermen must be protected. The trust that European consumers place in food products ought not be tarnished. A guarantee of the products’ legal origin must be secured, and standards set for sustainable fishing applied equally across the board.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — This proposal for a Resolution by Parliament calls for the generalised system of preferences not to be granted until the Philippines ends illegal fishing, child trafficking, etc. The EU grants the GSP+ system to third countries on the condition that they ratify and respect 27 international conventions, some of which the Philippines is not respecting.  I voted in favour of Parliament's motion for a resolution as it calls for the GSP+ system not to be granted until guarantees are given by the Philippines.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — The Generalised Scheme of Preferences allows developing country exporters to pay less or no duties on their exports to the EU. This gives them vital access to EU markets whilst promoting trade and development.  GSP+ is granted to countries providing they ratify and implement 27 international conventions relating to human and labour rights, environment and good governance. A revised, more stringent GSP regulation came into effect in 2014, for which the Philippines fulfils the criteria and therefore applied for. However, certain Members believe that we should reject the Philippines application and a motion for objection was tabled due to the Philippines ‘yellow card’ under the EU’s Illegal, Unreported, and Unregulated Fishing Regulation.  Although the Commission has found issues related to the Philippines’ compliance with the Illegal unreported and unregulated Regulation, this does not affect the Philippines’ compliance with the 27 Conventions (including the environment-related ones) required for entry to GSP+. The Philippines has committed to investigating and improving the situation. Considering additional criteria beyond those set out in the GSP, such as the IUU, is outside the scope of the agreement reached by both Member States and Parliament. Hence I voted against this motion objecting to the Philippines’ application.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. — (IT) In line with my group, I voted against the objection made by some colleagues to the philippines that the special incentive scheme for sustainable development and good governance (GSP+) should be granted to the Philippines. I believe, in fact, that the granting of the GSP+ regime to the Philippines, on the basis of compliance with the criteria laid down in the recent reform of the European Generalised System of Preferences (GSP), could be a serious test for the Government of Manila and a significant encouragement on our part to continue with even greater conviction on the path taken to improve the implementation of international conventions on respect for human rights. , labour rights and, in this particular case, to stem the phenomenon of illegal fishing in the country. It is also clear that the granting of the special GSP+ scheme to the Philippines must involve a constant review by the EU of the commitments made by the Philippine Government and, in the event of their non-compliance, the decision taken today can and must be reviewed.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the proposal not to accept the request of the Philippines, which commit illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. In addition, the Philippines illegally uses mainly women and children for forced labour in fishing.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - We regret that it was not possible to achieve a qualified majority to adopt Parliament's resolution of objection to the Delegated Act granting the GSP+ to the Philippines. First, because the statute is granted before the Commission has withdrawn its notification to the Philippines as a third country considered uncooperative in the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing (IUU). The Commission has notified the Philippines that it could be considered a non-cooperative country in the fight against illegal fishing and has initiated a process in which the Philippines has a reasonable time to respond to the notification and justify the situation, which has not yet occurred. Secondly, in view of the impact that the granting of this scheme to the Philippines could have on the domestic canning industry. Currently, the market Portuguese absorbs approximately 80 % of the national production of canned tuna. Given that the Philippines, like Thailand, is one of the world's leading producers of canned fish, with emphasis on canned tuna, a possible reduction in customs duties could result in the arrival on the domestic market of Philippine tuna preserves in large numbers, with inevitable negative effects on the domestic canning industry.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — The Commission has shown a yellow card and has initiated proceedings against the Philippines for illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. The UN also points out that "trafficking in human beings, especially women and children for the purpose of forced labour, is widespread in various sectors, such as agriculture, construction, fisheries, processing and services, in the Philippines".

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. — I believe very strongly in free trade, not aid, as the best way to help out developing nations and their people. The EU on the other hand will impose restrictive conditions on the Philippines, and basically politicise trade. All over the world, nations are turning to China, as they do not place burdensome restrictions on them, as the EU does. Free trade is just that; ‘free’ without all of these restrictions weighted in the favour of the EU. I also do not agree that the EU has the right to create free trade deals for the British people – that is the job of Parliament (Westminster).

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. - I voted against this motion for resolution because the Philippines worked hard to meet the revised, more stringent GSP regulation and it succeeded in fulfilling all criteria What message are we sending if we now start adding criteria beyond those set out in the GSP to the list of requirements, like the Illegal, Unreported, and Unregulated Fishing Regulation?   Sustainable fishery is crucial, but changing the wording of a contract after it has already been signed is something credible partners simply do not do.   We also need to be consistent: Panama also had a yellow card under the IUU Regulation but was still approved for GSP+. When I visited Philippines in September, I was able to see through the many bilateral meetings I had that the Aquino government is on the right track. But much work remains to be done, and the opportunity offered by GSP+ to help bring inclusive growth in the Philippines is much needed.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted AGAINST The Commission's Delegated Regulation resolution amending Annex III on the application of the general customs preferences system on the ground that the country concerned does not implement the necessary requirements in the area of sustainable fishing, affecting European fishermen and consumers. In addition, they drastically violate the rights to the protection of the sea and in a completely uloyal way exert exploitation of marine resources and marine organisms. Unfortunately, it is also known that certain human rights are not respected and this is an additional motive for my opposition. Moreover, such a decision is in line with a proposal made within ALDE.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. — I regret that Parliament voted against the resolution brought by the French delegation of the EPP Group denying the Philippines access to the generalised preference system SPG. Unfortunately, the European Parliament has chosen to allow access to the European market at zero tariffs, although it is impossible to trace the legal origin of some of these products. This goes against the search for a level playing field for our European fishermen.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution on the Commission Delegated Regulation of 19 August 2014 amending Annex III to Regulation (EU) No 978/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council on the application of a system of generalised tariff preferences for the Philippines. I believe, in fact, that the European Commission's comments on the subject of violations of fundamental human rights in the Philippines are of particular concern and therefore require a change in the current text.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — This proposal for a Resolution by Parliament calls for the generalised system of preferences not to be granted until the Philippines ends illegal fishing, child trafficking, etc. The EU grants the GSP+ system to third countries on the condition that they ratify and respect 27 international conventions, some of which the Philippines is not respecting.  I voted in favour of Parliament's motion for a resolution as it calls for the GSP+ system not to be granted until guarantees are given by the Philippines.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — I supported the Report amending Annex III of the Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on the application of the general customs preferences system. In my view, the European Commission must delay the inclusion of the Philippines in the system of general preferences. Entering the general benefits system would not include customs duties on imports on 66% of tariff items to the Philippines. The Philippines must make further efforts to prevent human trafficking and the exploitation of work in women and children. It should also be noted that the Philippines must make great efforts to prevent illegal and unreported fishing. If the Philippines were granted entry into the general benefits system at the moment, these undeclared and illegal products would be on the EU market.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the Commission's delegated regulation of 19 August amending Annex III to Regulation (EU) No 1782/2003. 978/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council on the implementation of a system of generalised tariff preferences, as it deals adequately and appropriately with the subject matter which it regulates.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. — I voted against this resolution which sought to block the Philippines receiving the preferential trading scheme GSP+. This scheme is for vulnerable countries which sign, ratify and commit to implementing the 27 core ILO conventions on labour, environmental and human rights standards. The Philippines has done this and now serious scrutiny and monitoring will begin by the Commission and Parliament. I objected to the resolution because, although there are concerns about illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing in the Philippines, this should be addressed separately. If their current ‘yellow’ card became ‘red’, fish imports to the EU will be blocked. But the technical and non-political criteria for GSP+ is within WTO rules and is the beginning of the process of monitoring, not the end.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — On 28 February 2014, the Commission received a request from the Republic of the Philippines for participation in the GSP (system of generalised tariff preferences). I have decided to support this resolution because I fully agree with the demand that this request can only be accepted and that the Philippines will make a real commitment to eliminate illegal fishing. This is based on the assumption that the Commission does not have the power to authorise preferential access to the European market for fishery products from the Philippines, without any guarantee of their legal origin being offered.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — (DE) I voted in favour of the proposal to reject the delegated regulation, because the European Union must at all costs prevent products from IUU fishing from flowing into the European market. The Philippines, as a non-cooperative country in this respect, should not benefit from a tariff advantage. I would also point out that trafficking in human beings also contributes to the Philippines being stripped of ASP+ status for the time being.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — Regulation (EU) 978/2012 on the Generalized Tariff Preference Scheme (GSP) empowers the Commission to adopt delegated actions to establish or modify the list of GSP-receiving countries. On 19 August 2014, the Commission adopted a delegated regulation applying a scheme of generalised tariff preferences to the Philippines, which consists of exempting certain imports from that country from customs duties. However, the Philippines is an "uncooperative" player in the fight against illegal fishing. In addition, the UN report on human trafficking notes that "trafficking in human beings, especially women and children, for exploitation as labour, proliferates in various sectors, including agriculture, construction, fishing, manufacturing and services". It would also be illogical to grant the Philippines a scheme of generalized tariff preferences, since they do not comply with the conditions that are supposed to allow access to the GSP. I am voting for this resolution which opposes the Commission's delegated regulation.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — I endorsed and voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the Philippines should only have a special status in trade relations with the EU when they comply with all the rules required. Specifically with regard to combating illegal fishing and the exploitation of women and children.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I am not in agreement with this resolution.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The purpose of this motion for a resolution is to object to the granting of GSP tariff preferences to the Philippines. The EU's generalised system of tariff preferences (GSP) allows tariff reductions or duty-free access to the EU market for exports from 178 developing countries and territories. For example, for competing imports of canned tuna, granting the Philippines GSP tariff preferences would increase tariffs to 0%, from the current 24%. Such a measure could effectively amplify the unfair competition already faced by European fishermen. European fishermen who are already subject to abusive and very restrictive regulations. In addition, the Philippines has not yet provided guarantees of compliance with the conventions required to benefit from the GSP. Finally, the country must respond to an investigation into illegal, undeclared, unregistered fishing (INT fishing). In view of these different elements, I voted for this text.

name: Alessandra MORETTI
text: in writing. — (IT) I regret today's vote because I believe that the Request for GSP + of the Republic of the Philippines should not be accepted at the moment, given the non-cooperative state in the fight against illegal fishing. The EU cannot authorise preferential access to the European market for fishery products without having a guarantee of their legal origin. We cannot set a precedent of this kind, not only in view of the efforts we have made to our fishermen in the area of sustainability. Despite the progress made in this country, we cannot ignore a whole series of problems and violations which relate in particular to the problem of trafficking in persons, especially women and children, in the exploitation of labour in various sectors, including agriculture, construction and fisheries. I hope, however, that, should the yellow card turn into a red card, the decision will be taken to revoke the GSP+ system.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. — (IT) We have voted against this motion for a resolution on the application of the Generalised System of Preferences Plus (SGP+) to the Philippines, because on the one hand we believe that, since the Philippines has ratified the 27 UN/ILO conventions necessary for the granting of the programme, there is no formal obstacle and, on the other hand, we are convinced of the usefulness of the SGP+ in supporting the economic, political and social development of the Philippines. In addition, it should be stressed that the SGP+ mechanism has recently been renewed and tightened up, with new possibilities for sanctions that can go as far as withdrawing the programme. Politically, the granting of the programme is the most effective way, on the one hand, to improve the situation in the country, which was made even more complicated by Typhoon Hagugit at the beginning of December, and, on the other, to be able to influence certain strategic choices through monitoring and sanction mechanisms. It is also worth remembering that the granting of the SGP+ is not a gift, but only the starting point of a years-long journey that aims to make a state in difficulty better economically, politically and socially.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, because I believe that the Commission should wait until the situation of illegal fishing and respect for fundamental rights are properly dealt with by the Government of the Philippines and that, in the meantime, it is premature to grant them generalised tariff preferences.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I didn't. Illegal fishing must first be severely restricted.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: In writing. "I voted against this resolution granting the GSP to the Philippines. Granting GSP status in the Philippines is tantamount to opening the floodgates to social and environmental dumping. Indeed, the archipelago specializes in the canning of fish. Labelling should only include the place where the fish was canned, not where it was caught. It's a perfect way to whiten illegally caught fish.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — Ladies and gentlemen, illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing is still practised in the Philippines, which is guaranteed the generalised system of tariff preferences with the EU. The Philippine Government is called upon to prevent and eradicate this practice, not only to ensure environmental sustainability, but also to protect competition and protect European consumers. Considering that as long as the State of the Philippines does not demonstrate that it is actively cooperating in the fight against illegal fishing, GSP+ status should be suspended, I intend to vote in favour.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — I supported the Commission's Delegated Regulation resolution on the application of the system of general customs preferences to the Philippines, as I consider that the conclusion of an agreement allowing preferential imports of products originating in a country that does not sufficiently do so to stop actions opposed to the principles and rules we promote in the European Union should be postponed. In August 2014, the European Commission adopted a Delegated Regulation on the application of the general customs preferences system for the Philippines. This Regulation would allow the Philippines to export certain product groups to the EU. In 2008, a Council regulation was adopted defining rules aimed at establishing a Community to prevent, combat and stop illegal, unreported and irregular fishing. On 10 June 2014, the Commission adopted a decision indicating to the Philippines that there is considered to be a possibility of identifying the Philippines as a non-cooperating State in accordance with that Regulation.  Illegal fish catching from the world's seas causes enormous damage annually. The sale of illegally fish makes it difficult to assess the real economic impact of illegal harvesting, but experts consider it a serious threat to legitimate fisheries employing millions of people worldwide.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: in writing. — Although I do not want to question the UN Special Rapporteur's findings on the situation of labour exploitation in the fisheries sector, I could not support the proposal, mainly because I know that the Philippines is working intensively to address the situation. In my opinion, the proposed measures and the actual effects of the resolution are disproportionate and I have to wonder what impact they may have on the relationship between the EU and the Philippines. This position of mine is justified only by the fact that the Philippines is trying really sincerely to remedy the situation, and I accept that if improvements are not noticeable in the foreseeable future, then I will reconsider my view.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. "I have been fighting for months, first in my Committee on International Trade and then in plenary session, to defend our fishermen and fellow citizens by preventing illegal fishing products from the Philippines from coming to our territory. The resolution I tabled with my colleague Alain Cadec, Chairman of the Committee on Fisheries, received broad support, but not the qualified majority, necessary for it to be approved. In doing so, the European Parliament has just authorised the Philippines to export products from illegal fishing to the European market without tariffs, it makes no sense! To our fishermen, it is a provocation! They will face unfair competition from the Philippines. And to our consumers, it's a mistake! The European Commission is unable to guarantee them the legality of the fish products they will consume in the coming months. Our trading partners must respect the rules against illegal fishing as European fishermen do, it is a question of consistency. Together with my colleagues from the French EPP delegation, I will remain vigilant.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — The generalised system of preferences consists of a general scheme and two special schemes, including the special incentive scheme for sustainable development and good governance (GSP+), without the collection of import duties from beneficiary countries in relation to 66 % of all EU tariff positions. On 28 February 2014, the Commission received a request for GSP+ from the Republic of the Philippines, which proposes to accept, pursuant to the Commission's Delegated Regulation (C(2014)05833) of 19 August 2014.  In view of the risk that, by decision of 10 June 2014, the Commission notified the Republic of the Philippines of the risk of being identified as a third country which is not cooperative in the fight against illegal fishing (IUU), I do not think it makes sense to grant the Philippines GSP+ status at this stage. Such a measure will introduce unfair conditions of competition for European fishermen, seriously harming the interests of several Member States, including Portugal. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution which opposes that delegated regulation, relegating the granting of SGP+ status to the Philippines for a later stage when conditions are met for the withdrawal of notification under the IUU procedure.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — I voted against this resolution of objection to the granting to the Philippines of GSP+ status. The Philippines, the current beneficiary of the system of generalised preferences, has formally requested the EU to be accorded GSP+ treatment and meets the eligibility criteria generally set out in EU Regulation No 978/2012. However, the parliamentary processing of this concession comes at a time when DG MARE of the Commission has opened a dossier and gave an ultimatum to the Philippines, by means of a 'yellow card', for illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing practices. This regrettable situation of lack of coordination of political action by the Commission risks that, from the approval of the GSP+ to the possible import ban on fisheries products from the Philippines, products obtained through illegal fishing practices will be imported into the EU. Should the Philippines be convicted of unlawful fishing with a 'red card', the European Commission shall assess the damage caused to European producers during the GSP+ implementation period, as well as fair compensation.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. — I voted for this resolution, which calls for the generalised tariff preference scheme not to be granted to the Philippines until the European Commission has cancelled the notification that the Philippines could be considered a non-cooperative third country in the fight against illegal fishing. It should be noted that the resolution does not state that it opposes any future request from the Philippines or the granting by the Union of GSP status in the near future. I have also asked the Commission to draw up, in close collaboration with the relevant UN bodies, NGOs and the Philippine government, a roadmap on human rights and the environment, including fishing practices, in order to set targets that the Philippines will need to achieve in 2015 to be able to apply for GSP status by 2016.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — Because I believe that the European Union has to be a credible international actor and promote coherence in its action, because I believe that third countries our partners have to comply with the same rules to which we are subject, namely those relating to human rights, labour, environmental preservation and (good) governance, because I believe that our industrial sector, in particular the canning industry (but also textiles and clothing and bicycles) , has to be protected from unfair competition practices by third-country companies, I was one of the promoters of this resolution (and previously the resolution on the same subject that was voted on in the INTA committee) which aimed to prevent the immediate allocation of a fairly broad set of customs benefits to the Philippines (GSP+). Unfortunately, despite a greater number of votes in plenary (313 sins; 285 no), a qualified majority of 50 % + 1 vote was required for the adoption of this resolution (376 sins), which did not happen. We will therefore continue to be mindful of the development of this issue, in particular the commission's assessment of the Philippines over the next year, as well as the progress of the case-finding of iUU fisheries.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. — I supported this resolution opposing the Philippines' immediate access to the European Union's generalised preference system. Indeed, the Philippines received a yellow card this summer from the Commission on the practice of illegal fishing and is currently undergoing an investigation procedure; in this sense, we had to protect our French and European fishermen from any practice of unfair competition.  Unfortunately, the European Parliament did not support this resolution, which emphasised the need for consistency in European policies and insisted that our trading partners respect the rules against illegal fishing, as European fishermen do.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour because I believe it is right to protect the activity of European fishing vessels from unfair competition from fishermen from countries which do not comply with our own rules on fishing and labour exploitation.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - This proposal for a Resolution by Parliament calls for the generalised system of preferences not to be granted until the Philippines ends illegal fishing, child trafficking, etc. The EU grants the GSP+ system to third countries on the condition that they ratify and respect 27 international conventions, some of which the Philippines is not respecting.  I voted in favour of Parliament's motion for a resolution as it calls for the GSP+ system not to be granted until guarantees are given by the Philippines.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. — (IT) Before granting the Philippines the tariff preferences provided for by the GSP+ system, I think it is important to ensure that this country cooperates actively with the EU in the fight against illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing. We cannot, in fact, allow honest fishermen and fish producers to suffer unfair competition linked to the import and sale of tuna and other fish illegally caught in Philippine waters. First of all, we must give the Commission and, in particular, DG MARE time to clarify and complete the ongoing investigation. Let us not forget that the fight against illegal fishing is one of the cornerstones of the European Union's action to prevent the over-exploitation of fish stocks, to safeguard marine habitats and thus to ensure sustainable fishing. That is why any decision in the opposite direction would, in everyone's view, represent not only a clear contradiction in the interpretation of European priorities, but also a dangerous precedent. Once the Philippines shows that it has made real progress in taking effective management and control measures to tackle the problem of illegal fishing, we will be able to reassess the request for further tariff concessions.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — I voted with the majority against the motion for a resolution on generalised tariff preferences.  The Generalised System of Preferences consists of a general arrangement and two special arrangements, including the special incentive arrangement for sustainable development and good governance (GSP+), charging no duties on imports from beneficiaries for 66 % of all EU tariff lines.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — Unreported fisheries are common in countries that do not have strict control over the fisheries sector, which is why I supported this proposal. As the Philippines belongs to third world countries, it is inadmissible for the Union to in any way encourage illegal, unreported and unregulated fisheries. These procedures do not comply with the Council regulation and the actions jeopardise the sustainability of the fish stock. The Philippines must respond to the Council's formal decision as soon as possible and realise its position and the guidelines of the European Union.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. "We voted against this resolution. On the one hand because the Philippines does not respect the rules but on the other hand to send a signal. Indeed, we cannot continue to accept trade agreements or preferable tariffs with countries that do not respect human rights or social and environmental rights simply because we have always done so!

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — The generalised system of preferences consists of a general scheme and two special schemes, including the special scheme for encouraging sustainable development and good governance (GSP+), without the collection of any import duties from beneficiary countries in respect of 66 % of all EU tariff positions. The Commission, in its resolution of 17 November 2011 on combating illegal fishing worldwide, explicitly states that IUU fishing threatens the sustainability of fish stocks and that the concept of responsibility of the marketing State, as a means of prohibiting market access to IUU fishery products, needs to be further developed. We support this regulation while noting the contradiction in the Philippines process.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — (DE) I voted in favour of the proposal to reject the delegated regulation, because the European Union must at all costs prevent products from IUU fishing from flowing into the European market. Thus, the Philippines should not benefit from a tariff advantage in respect of this. It should also be noted that trafficking in human beings also contributes to the Philippines being stripped of ASP+ status until further notice.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — The smooth and timely implementation of the Banking Recovery and Resolution Directive framework by 1 January 2015 requires national resolution authorities to start calculating and collecting contributions to resolution financing structures by 1 January 2015. In order to achieve this, the delegated regulation governing this must enter into force as early as 2014, which is why I support this proposal.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this Recommendation for a Decision of the European Parliament, submitted in accordance with Article 105(6) of the Regulation, not to object to the Commission Delegated Regulation, 21 October 2014 supplementing Directive 2014/59/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of 15 May 2014 on ex ante contributions to resolution financing mechanisms (C(2014)07674 – 2014/2923(DEA)). I consider, as stated in the Recommendation itself, that the agreement in the Council on the Implementing Regulation specifying uniform conditions for the application of Regulation (EU) No 806/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council as regards ex ante contributions to the Single Resolution Fund, reached after parliament's informal participation, is consistent with the abovementioned Delegated Regulation, among other factors also expressed in this Recommendation.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution because it seeks to enable the Commission to apply effectively the so-called Bank Recovery and Resolution Directive. In order to apply the Directive, Member States must ensure that contributions are collected at least once a year from the credit institutions and investment firms concerned authorised in the territory of those countries. These contributions from credit institutions and investment firms shall be adjusted to take account of the risk profile of those institutions and may be made by the Commission only by means of delegated acts approved by the European Parliament.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The SRB (Single Resolution Council) is the cornerstone of the Single Resolution Mechanism (MRU), which will soon be responsible for implementing the dismantling of "banks in distress" through a series of instruments, including a single resolution fund abounded by banks and an arsenal of rules dealing with the hierarchy of creditors in the event of bankruptcy. The MRU will apply to banks covered by the MSU, which makes the European Central Bank (ECB) the central prudential supervisor of euro area banking institutions (approximately 6,000 banks). The MRU will respond in cases where a bank fails despite enhanced supervision. It will be based on a 6-member board. Aware of the need to prevent the failure of banks, however, I remain firmly committed to national sovereignty; that is why I voted against it.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — I am voting in favour: the Directive on the management and resolution of banking crises (BRRD) lays down the rules for the intervention of shareholders and creditors of banks, both in the event of a revival or restructuring of the institution and in the event of its bankruptcy. In the event of future banking crises, the costs will be paid by the credit institutions themselves, with a system of compulsory contributions.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. - This motion seeks ‘no objection’ to a Delegated Act which calculates annual contributions from financial institutions to their national Resolution Authority’s resolution financing arrangements; and sets penalties for late payment. Accordingly, I voted against it.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of this regulation, which concerns ex ante contributions to the financing mechanisms of the resolution. I agree with the decision not to raise any objections to the Rules of Procedure. I agree with the assessments made and, above all, with the fact that Member States must ensure that contributions are collected at least annually from the relevant credit institutions and investment firms authorised in their territory.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — Resolution financing arrangements need to be sufficiently funded to allow for a proper functioning of the resolution framework and protect financial stability without recourse to taxpayers’ money. It is also in the interest of the banking sector that the financing arrangements have enough resources to intervene where necessary for the effective application of the resolution tools. I have no objection to the delegated regulation of the Commission so I voted in favour.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of Parliament’s resolution declaring that it has no objections to this delegated regulation, in line with the Implementing Regulation specifying uniform conditions of application of Regulation (EU) No 806/2014 with regard to ex-ante contributions to the Single Resolution Fund.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — I voted against the proposal, as I am opposed to the existence of the single resolution fund and ex ante contributions to financial resolution arrangements.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. — The missing element of the Banking Union relates to a delegated act relating to ex ante contributions to the resolution financing mechanisms, which lays down how much banks need to pay to the resolution fund. One of the problems with this particular act is that it does not guarantee that the fixed contributions reflect the risk profile of banks appropriately. In other words, healthy banks with conservative business models and institutional guarantee systems such as cooperative banks that will probably never need any resolution funds will be called upon to pay the risks that those who play in the financial markets. This paves the way for an unfair distribution of the financing costs of resolution funds that especially hurts low-risk local banks. Failure to object to this delegated act is an undemocratic act and an escape from scrutiny of the Commission's activity by the European Parliament, an unacceptable blank cheque. In addition to our principled position on the Banking Union, they are plenty of reasons for our vote against.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — We disagree more generally with the existence of the single resolution fund and the ex ante contributions to financial resolution arrangements.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for a resolution not to object to the Commission Delegated Regulation amending Directive 2014/59/EU concerning ex ante contributions to financial arrangements for resolution so that the Delegated Regulation can enter into force.  The Delegated Regulation can only enter into force if Parliament does not object to the Commission's delegated regulations and therefore I have accepted this Resolution. This allows for the smooth and timely implementation of the BRRD Framework, allowing NRAs to immediately calculate and collect contributions to financial arrangements for resolution, as the calculation and collection of contributions is carried out in accordance with that Delegated Regulation.  The motive for voting on ex ante contributions to the Single Resolution Fund was also the fact that all this was achieved after parliament's informal involvement. An additional motive is certainly the position of the ALDE Group, which, like the vast majority in the European Parliament, supports the resolution in matter.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in today's vote I supported the regulation on ex ante contributions to the mechanisms for financing the resolution. I fully agree with the rapporteur's decision not to raise any objections, as I agree with the comments made by the Commission. I also support the desirability of the obligation for Member States to ensure that contributions are collected, at least every year, from the relevant authorised bodies in the territory of reference.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I voted against the recommendation of a decision not to object to the Commission's delegated regulation of 21 October 2014 to supplement Directive 2014/59/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of 15 May 2014 on ex ante contributions to financial resolution arrangements, as I do not agree with the delegation of powers to the Commission in this respect. Moreover, this recommendation for a decision does not adequately address the issues it is supposed to want to address.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — Under the Single Resolution Mechanism, the relevant national authorities must levy contributions to financial crisis resolution mechanisms. These contributions must be adapted to the risk profile of institutions and companies according to the criteria specified in a Commission delegated act. However, in the delegated act adopted by the Commission, the contributions do not adequately reflect the level of risk of the banks. Thus "healthy" banks must contribute as much as the most speculative financial institutions. I am voting against the recommendation that approves this delegated act.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this recommendation because I have no objections to the delegated regulation so as to ensure that banks are more resilient to future shocks.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I am in agreement with the ex-ante contributions to resolution financing agreements.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The SRB (Single Resolution Council) is the cornerstone of the Single Resolution Mechanism (MRU), which will soon be responsible for implementing the dismantling of "banks in distress" through a series of instruments, including a single resolution fund abounded by banks and an arsenal of rules dealing with the hierarchy of creditors in the event of bankruptcy. The MRU will apply to banks covered by the MSU, which makes the European Central Bank (ECB) the central prudential supervisor of euro area banking institutions (approximately 6,000 banks). The MRU will respond in cases where a bank fails despite enhanced supervision. It will be based on a 6-member board. Aware of the need to prevent the failure of banks, however, I remain firmly committed to national sovereignty; that is why I voted against it.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — After careful consideration of the text, I should like to vote in favour.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — Article 103 of the DRRB Directive provides that Member States shall ensure that at least annual contributions are required from credit institutions and investment firms authorised in their territory. Such contributions shall be adjusted in proportion to the risk profile of the institutions in accordance with the criteria specified by the Commission in a delegated act to be adopted in accordance with paragraph 7 of that standard. On the basis of this empowerment, the Commission adopted on 21 October 2014 a delegated regulation supplementing the DRRB Directive with regard to ex ante contributions to resolution financing mechanisms. However, in order for the implementation of the DRRB Directive to take place by 1 January 2015, it is necessary that the national resolution authorities start calculating and collecting contributions as soon as possible and that the agreement on the Council Implementing Regulation, which specifies the uniform conditions of application of Regulation (EU) No 806/2014 with regard to ex ante contributions to the Single Resolution Fund, is consistent with the delegated regulation in question here, I voted in favour of this decision not to raise objections to it.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour because the measure aims to ensure that, in the event of future banking crises, the costs are paid by the credit institutions themselves, whose compulsory contributions will fuel a specially set up fund.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of a motion for a resolution on financing arrangements. Article 130 of Directive (EU) No 59/2014 (the BRRD Directive) requires Member States to apply the national measures necessary to comply with that Directive from 1 January 2015. In order to apply the Directive, Member States must ensure that contributions are raised at least annually from the relevant credit institutions and investment firms (‘the institutions’) authorised in their territory.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — I support this Resolution as it encourages an effective way of regulating financial arrangements for resolution, in particular, the efficient collection of contributions by credit institutions and investment firms.  The effective implementation of the directive enables the collection of contributions, while taking into account the risks of the institutions itself. In this way, national authorities will also be able to calculate and collect contributions in a timely manner. To this end, it is necessary to adopt this Resolution as soon as possible.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — We disagree more generally with the existence of the single resolution fund and the ex ante contributions to financial resolution arrangements.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the Commission's Delegate Regulation (EU) complementing the 2014/59/EU Directive of the European Parliament and the Council of 15 May 2014 with regard to ex ante contributions to the funding schemes for the resolution.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — The missing element of the banking union relates to a delegated act relating to ex ante contributions to the resolution financing mechanisms, which lays down how much banks need to pay to the resolution fund. One of the problems with this particular act is that it does not guarantee that the fixed contributions reflect the risk profile of banks appropriately. In other words, healthy banks with conservative business models and institutional guarantee systems, such as cooperative banks that are unlikely to need any resolution funds, will be called upon to pay the risks of those playing in financial markets. This paves the way for an unfair distribution of the financing costs of resolution funds, which especially hurts low-risk local banks. The early lifting of a non-objection to this delegated act, in addition to being an undemocratic act and escaping scrutiny of the Commission's activity by the European Parliament, is a blank cheque that we cannot accept.

name: Marek JUREK
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. We have decided to association between the European Union and Georgia and, of course, I voted in favour of the resolution, because anything that strengthens the independence of the eastern states after the break-up of the Soviet Union fulfils the mandates of European solidarity. But I must express my disapproval of the fact that Georgia is imposing a homosexual ideology that contradicts this solidarity. The social capital of Europe was the Georgian Family March, which was attended by thousands of Tbilisi residents at the appeal of the Orthodox Church. And the accusation of homophobia against Georgia is a real attack on the values contained in the law of central European countries, from Lithuania to Croatia. I appeal specifically to the Christian Democrats: do not accept the culture of the far left, vote as Schuman, Adenauer and De Gasperi would have voted.  And of course Joyeux Noël, Merry Christmas and Merry Christmas to all.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Madam President, I, as a Member from the Czech Republic, a former post-communist country with tragic experience with the Soviet Union, have been very welcome and very welcome that today we have adopted and supported the Georgia Association Agreement, opening the way for this country, which was once part of the Soviet Union and where Russia still exercises its influential interests, among democratic states, among the family of European democratic rule of law. In my opinion, this is very important and it is very important that our policy, that of the European Union, supports these former parts and former countries of the communist bloc and that it allows them to become legal and prosperous states. At the last meeting, we supported Moldova in this way, now we support Georgia in this way, and I hope that this agreement will benefit Georgia in the development of the legal State of Georgia and in the development of the Georgian economy. I therefore consider this to be very important and I am glad that our policy is geared towards the development of this eastern part of Europe and, say, part of Asia. This is very important and I hope that we will continue to do so.

name: Tatjana ŽDANOKA
text: Madam President, I voted against the consent and the resolution, which bears the spirit of division and not of integration of the European continent as a whole, and of the South Caucasus region in particular. The wording ‘varying levels of ambition and capacity’ with regard to the three South Caucasus states is a humiliating one. The proposal to create a specific EU-Georgia PCC, considering the varying scope of relations with Armenia and Azerbaijan, is going in that direction as well. South Ossetia and Abkhazia are referred to as ‘occupied territories’, and Russia is called on ‘to end its occupation thereof’. This is despite the well-known EU investigation claiming that ‘open hostilities’ began with a large-scale Georgian military operation against Tskhinvali.  The statement that ‘the association process is not a threat to Russia’s political and economic interests’ remains a declaration confirmed by nothing. Therefore, the assertion that ‘the EU’s engagement with the Eastern Partners aims to spread prosperity… from which all countries in the region will gain’ is doubtful.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Madam President! I voted in favour of the agreement because it is quite simply a start and because, as has already been said, it is a historic moment. How can you make the world a better place? You can make the world a better place by trading, by treating each other with respect, by treating each other with respect, and by simply building trust. For me, this is a great confidence-building measure.  We are also providing the region and the country with alternatives and together – And I repeat – we are helping to make the world a little better. In this respect, for me, this is a blueprint for further association agreements, that we, as the European Union, can bring not only our economic but also our political values to other regions. To vote against it today, for me, is to leave this region a little far alone.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: Madam President, we should not allow the immediacy of the crisis in Ukraine to blind us to older instances of Putinite revanchism. Here is a situation where Russia continues to occupy part of a sovereign neighbouring country, but this is not just about territory and it is not just about annexations. Something bigger is in the balance. If I can borrow a 19th century Russian analogy, this is a conflict that we have seen throughout the former Soviet Union between what we might call Slavophiles and Westernisers, between those who choose democracy and those who choose the Führerprinzip, between those who want a liberal society and those who want an autocratic society. Essentially it is about the rule of law. It is about not having governments that get to make up the rules as they go along without there being any independent authority. Of course, it is for the people of Georgia – as it is for the people of Ukraine and every other country – to make their decision, but if they choose the direction of Western liberal values, then we have a duty to support them. By ‘we’ I do not just mean the European Union, I mean the entire Euro-Atlantic community. Force of arms should never be allowed to trump force of argument. .

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: Madam President, once again this Chamber has voted for a motion that will lead to increased neo-colonialism of the European Union and its supporters of imperialism in this Chamber. The consequences of this at Christmas would be laughable if it were not serious. In my constituency of the North-West there is a town called Stockport. Thousands of people this Christmas will be struggling to eat and heat their homes; they will be seeking food from food banks.  This House today has voted to take money from the European Union and give it to dictators and bureaucrats in Georgia through agreements. You are taking money and food from the mouths of my constituents to give it to the greedy in Georgia. I opposed this motion along with UKIP, my party, because we do not believe in EU imperialism; we do not believe that you can take money from the poor to give to the rich; we do not believe that the people of Stockport should have a poor Christmas just because the Georgian rich want a rich Christmas.

name: Seán KELLY
text: Madam President, contrary to the last speaker, I was very pleased to support this motion and vote for my Group accordingly. I think it is a landmark day, and it is significant that we had the President and the former President here to witness our democratic decisions. The vast majority of Members voted in favour of this. Of course, there are those who disagree, and they are entitled to their opinions, but democracy is based on the majority. I also think that Georgia wants to express its democratic right to look to the West rather than be strangled by the East for evermore.
