Giving them consideration here, at European Parliament level, is an indication of our willingness and desire to ensure that all peoples are free, that all governments can make choices of their own, and fundamentally that we are going to support that around the world. This is a good day for Georgia and a good day for the European Union.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — I voted against this report which gives its approval to the conclusion of an Association Agreement with Georgia, which entails the creation of a large free trade area between the EU and Georgia. I have always voted against the creation of free trade zones between the EU and third countries on the understanding that they always benefit large companies and large European capital, to the detriment of local production by third countries. In this case it couldn't be any other way. Moreover, it has become clear that in the case of Georgia the intention is to bring Georgia closer to the orbit of the EU and NATO, and to move it as far away from Russia's influence as possible, which is an interference in Georgia's internal affairs. That's why I voted against it.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. - Conclusion of the Association agreement with Georgia Report: Andrejs Mamikins (A8-0042/2014). This Association Agreement between the EU and Georgia refers to the Free Trade Agreement between the EU and Georgia as one of the most ambitious FTAs that the EU has negotiated with a third country. It talks about a Deep and Comprehensive FTA, modernising the country’s economy – which concerns privatisation and liberalisation – and commends Georgia for undertaking deep and difficult economic reforms. In the Irish experience these ‘reforms’ tend to make the rich richer and the vast majority of the people poorer. Some of the references to Russia are not helpful, given the on-going tensions in the region. Integration into NATO is not likely to ease tensions. For these reasons I voted against this motion.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of concluding an Association Agreement with Georgia. This association and free trade agreement is intended to strengthen the economic and political ties between the European Union and Georgia. It will become the third treaty of its kind that the European Parliament ratifies with the EU's eastern neighbours. In September this year, the Commission adopted a proposal for a directive on the protection of the environment and The EP has already ratified a similar treaty with Ukraine, and in November the European Parliament adopted a resolution calling on the European Parliament to take part in the agreement. – with Moldova. The creation of a comprehensive free trade area with the EU should increase market access to the EU's economic bloc through binding commitments on standards and common values, while the EU will benefit from smoother trade flows and better conditions for investment in Georgia. It is important that both Parties engage in constructive dialogue in order to confirm the main reforms and commitments provided for in the Association Agreement. The priorities set out in the Agreement should be adequately technically and financially supported in order to ensure that Georgia has the means to continue its democratic and economic reforms.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. — Georgia must continue its efforts to strengthen democracy. It is important that the country continues on this path, and that is why signing an association agreement with it is an important and encouraging act. In addition to the benefits that Georgia will derive from this agreement, the European Union will benefit from more regular trade flows and better investment conditions in Georgia. At the same time, it is of course necessary for the Georgian authorities to work towards national reconciliation and to continue to consolidate human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This proposal for a non-legislative resolution on the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States, on the one hand, and Georgia, on the other, must eventually enable Georgia to join the European Union. This is the hidden side of this agreement! On the principle of 'more funds, more reforms', the Union intends on the one hand to squander European taxpayers' money in Georgia when it is sorely lacking and, on the other hand, to impose on Georgia its ultra-liberal vision, which has still not been proven.  This agreement is a new attack on Russia, with which our relations are more than tense: a demand for respect for Georgia's territorial integrity, an insistence that Russia reverse its decision to recognize the secession of the Georgian regions of Abkhazia and Tskhinvali in South Ossetia, and that it end the occupation.  For these and other reasons, I voted against the conclusion of this association agreement.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — I support this motion for a Resolution, which accompanies the Recommendation on the Association Agreement with Georgia, in which, among other issues, we welcom the progress made in Abkhazia and South Ossetia, as well as in relations with Russia.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution because it reaffirmed its support and support for Georgia, while supporting the conclusion of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement on behalf of the European Union. In this resolution, Parliament warmly welcomed Georgia's signing of the Association Agreement, as an important step forward in the development of bilateral relations and reinforces the commitment to the path of political association and economic integration. Parliament stresses in its resolution the importance of a constructive dialogue involving all parties in order to confirm the main reforms and commitments provided for in the Association Agreement, based on a common choice for European integration. The resolution also calls for Georgia to ensure that reforms are anchored and deeply rooted in the institutional framework, so that a society with pluralism, non-discrimination, tolerance, justice, solidarity and equality between women and men can be created.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. — The rapporteur "congratulates Georgia for controlling pressure from other countries, including Russia." Is this really useful and timely given the geopolitical situation in the region and the current tensions between the European Union and the Russian Federation? It is highly doubtful. As for the economic consequences, lessons must be learned from past experiences of bringing structurally very different economies closer together. Look at our German neighbors. The report promises Georgia "a European perspective and [the possibility of] applying to become a member of the Union". That is not reasonable. I therefore voted against this text which, on the one hand, can have disastrous economic consequences for the Member States and, on the other hand, is particularly delicate given the geopolitical context.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. — This Association Agreement between the EU and Georgia refers to the Free Trade Agreement between the EU and Georgia as one of the most ambitious FTAs that the EU has negotiated with a third country. It talks about a Deep and Comprehensive FTA, modernising the country’s economy – which concerns privatisation and liberalisation – and commends Georgia for undertaking deep and difficult economic reforms. In the Irish experience these ‘reforms’ tend to make the rich richer and the vast majority of the people poorer. Some of the references to Russia are not helpful, given the on-going tensions in the region. Integration into NATO is not likely to ease tensions. For these reasons I voted against this motion.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. "I voted against all the proposed amendments. The conclusion of the Association Agreement with Georgia is just one more manoeuvre put in place by the European Union to isolate Russia. This association agreement is part of a very worrying leak from the European Union, which does not meet any major interest.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a non-legislative resolution on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States, of the one part, and Georgia, of the other part. In Georgia there is a strong national consensus, but also at the level of all parties, in favour of the integration of this country into both the European Union and NATO. According to a recent study by the National Democratic Institute for International Affairs, 69% of Georgia's population agrees to sign an association agreement with the European Union. Georgia's progress in respect for human rights, democracy and the rule of law is crowned by the signing of the Association Agreement.  This commitment shows the EU's strong recognition of these advances, as well as Georgia's ambition to continue the pro-European path. The EU shows solidarity with both Georgia and the Republic of Moldova and Ukraine and the Agreement is not an end in itself, but part of a broad process of bringing these countries closer to the European ideal.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — (IT) I am voting against: this agreement offers Georgia a European perspective and can apply for membership of the Union. This agreement is part of the EU's eastward enlargement policy, as already seen with Ukraine and Moldova, mainly in an anti-Russian function.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. — In short, the S&D Group supports the Association Agreement with Georgia as a tool for further democratisation and European integration. Reforming the judicial system to adapt it to EU rules should be a priority for the Georgian Government. The Group also unconditionally supports Georgia's territorial integrity and welcomes the steps taken by the Government to improve dialogue with Russia.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of this agreement which will allow free trade between the EU and Georgia: 29% of Georgia's international trade is already destined for the European market. But it is also a deeply symbolic decision for Georgia's transition from the Soviet era to the European era. There is a strong national consensus in Georgia for integration with the West. Georgia has made considerable progress in recent years with regard to human rights and democracy. This agreement can help speed up good governance and reforms of the Georgian judicial system. With regard to the problem of the situation in Abkhazia and South Ossetia, I hope that sooner or later the issue of territorial integrity can be resolved and that the European Union will be able to contribute to change. With the EU Monitoring Mission in Georgia (EUMM), the European Union provides concrete support for peace and stability along the 'hot' border areas with Abkhazia and South Ossetia. Yesterday, the Council extended the mandate of the EU Monitoring Mission in Georgia by two years, which shows that the Eu ropean Union continues to firmly support Georgia's sovereignty and territorial integrity within internationally recognised borders.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. — This Association Agreement between the EU and Georgia refers to the Free Trade Agreement between the EU and Georgia as one of the most ambitious FTAs that the EU has negotiated with a third country. It talks about a Deep and Comprehensive FTA, modernising the country's economy – which concerns privatisation and liberalisation – and commends Georgia for undertaking deep and difficult economic reforms. In the Irish experience these ‘reforms’ tend to make the rich richer and the vast majority of the people poorer. Some of the references to Russia are not helpful, given the ongoing tensions in the region. Integration into NATO is not likely to ease tensions. For these reasons I voted against this motion.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. - I voted against this proposal as this is an extension of EU influence in eastern Europe, which only exacerbates the current political tensions with the Russian Federation.  I believe the EU needs to stop building its own, new empire. Least of all, on the Russian border.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. — I voted against this EU-Georgia Association Agreement, which is nothing more than a hasty attempt to encircle Russia by the vassalisation of its strategic partners. Despite the accumulation of good intentions, the European Union once again shows in this text the will to trample on the sovereignty of nations: the motion for a resolution thus evokes the mandatory "compliance" of Georgian legislation. Worse, the European parliamentarians are praising a 'consensual European choice', in other words, they are calling for a genuine denial of the democratic principle! This interference is all the more scandalous because it is also harmful for the citizens of the Member States: it advocates intensive liberalisation of both markets and visas. For example, according to a recent report by The Economic Journal, immigration has cost GBP 150 billion in 17 years for a country like the United Kingdom, one of the countries that is best able to stem the effects of the economic crisis through its monetary sovereignty. This EU-Ukraine Association Agreement shows once again that the decisions taken by European bodies are dictated by ideology and not common sense.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - (IT) I am of the opinion that the Association Agreement between the European Union and Georgia represents one of the most ambitious free trade agreements that the EU has ever negotiated with a third country and considering Georgia's efforts in relation to reforms to promote human rights and democracy, in building a free society based on the rule of law, democracy and social pluralism and in pursuing closer economic ties with the European Union, I am voting in favour of this report for the conclusion of the Association Agreement. I hope that with today's vote Georgia will be better able to withstand the external pressure exerted by Russia in the Abkhazia and Tskhinvali/South Ossetia areas and redirect its exports to new markets, as well as having a positive long-term effect on the economy and thus contribute to improving the quality of life of its citizens.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — The Council authorised the Commission to open negotiations with Georgia for the conclusion of a new Agreement (DCFTA) to replace the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement. It is now necessary to conclude this Agreement on behalf of the European Union. I think that this Agreement is very favourable for the Member States, while the EU will benefit from smoother commercial flows and better investment conditions in Georgia. It is expected that the DCFTA will boost trade between the EU and Georgia by 12% as regards Georgia’s exports to the EU, and by 7.5% for imports from the EU. For this reason I voted in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — I voted against this report which gives its approval to the conclusion of an Association Agreement with Georgia, which entails the creation of a large free trade area between the EU and Georgia. I have always voted against the creation of free trade zones between the EU and third countries on the understanding that they always benefit large companies and large European capital, to the detriment of local production by third countries. In this case it couldn't be any other way. Moreover, it has become clear that in the case of Georgia the intention is to bring Georgia closer to the orbit of the EU and NATO, and to move it as far away from Russia's influence as possible, which is an interference in Georgia's internal affairs. That's why I voted against it.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — This is Parliamentʼs resolution accompanying the consent vote on the Association Agreement. I believe in strengthening relations between the European Union and neighbouring countries the likes of Georgia, hence I voted in favour of this Association Agreeement.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. — The EU-Georgia Association Agreement was initiated during the Eastern Partnership Summit in Vilnius on 29 November 2013 and signed on 27 June 2014. The Georgian Parliament ratified it on 18 July, allowing the agreement to enter into force provisionally on 1 September 2014. This agreement aims to significantly deepen Georgia's political association and gradual economic integration into the EU internal market. The Association Agreement also provides for many opportunities for sectoral cooperation and focuses on supporting key reforms, economic recovery and growth, governance and sectoral cooperation in 28 areas, including agriculture and rural development. Given the current geopolitical context in Eastern Europe and the Caucasus, this association agreement charts a European path for Georgia. For this reason, I am voting for the conclusion of this agreement.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The Union must develop strengthened partnerships with the countries in its neighbourhood. This association agreement will strengthen political ties with Tbilisi even as Georgia has carried out a major reform of its judicial system to improve its governance.  Through this agreement, Europeans and Georgians will be able to continue cooperation and dialogue on the reforms still to be pursued to anchor democracy and the rule of law.  This enhanced political cooperation will go hand in hand with the establishment of a Union-Georgia free trade area that promotes trade links between the two groups.  This agreement must, in the long run, enable the country to be modernized and stabilised, so that it can freely chart its future. In order to do so, it must be remembered that the agreement covers the entire Georgian territory and that in the future a lasting diplomatic solution will have to be found in the situations of Abkhazia and South Ossetia.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. — I welcome the European Parliament resolution approving the conclusion of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement, as it symbolises progress in its relations with the Union.  The implementation of the agreement as soon as possible is key to achieving political and economic progress in the country.  The Georgian authorities' efforts to implement democratic reforms, including those in the judiciary, must be noted, indicating that they are among the priorities of both the EU and georgian governments.  I support the fact that in its resolution the European Parliament underlines the importance of anti-discrimination legislation to ensure equal rights and protect minorities, including ethnic ones. As a Bulgarian representative, I am obliged to draw attention to the fact that in Georgia there is a traditional Bulgarian minority dating back to the second half of the 19th century, whose representatives in the past were treated as people of "unreliable origin" and were even sent to exile. I believe this agreement will provide a basis for guaranteeing their rights.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — I voted against the report, because the enlargement of the EU with the entry of the economically weak serves only the interests of the economically powerful states, without resolving the crisis affecting the countries of the South, while, in the long term, it will bring economic and social consequences to the acceding states equivalent to those experienced by our country.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - Georgia has made significant progress in terms of reforms and has strengthened its relations with the EU. Moreover, for the first time in Georgia's recent history, the transfer of powers after these elections took place peacefully and democratically, which could serve as an example for the whole region. The population of Georgia itself has approved by 69 % the signing of this Association Agreement which, as a significant advance in EU-Georgia relations, deserves my approval. This is a commitment that accentuates georgia's political association and economic integration that the EU has been helping as evidenced by the financial assistance granted to georgia in 2014.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — It is proposed to vote against the report, since the enlargement of the EU with the entry of economically weak states serves only the interests of the economically powerful states, without resolving the crisis affecting the countries of the South, while, in the long term, it will have economic and social consequences equivalent to those experienced by our country.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - We abstained in the vote on the ASSOCIATION Agreement between the EU and Georgia for the reasons set out below. We respect the decision of the people of Georgia, who have shown their support for the European project, and we are in favour of the EU fostering cooperation ties with neighbouring countries. However, we are critical of the content of this Agreement, which, inter alia, imposes on Georgia a gradual process of adapting to the European framework without clear financial support and without the right to participate in the political process which in the future could lead it to be a full member of the EU. The motion for a Resolution implys that the accession process is accelerated through the signing of the agreement, although no EU enlargement will take place until 2020.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. — The conclusion of an association agreement is an important step in the history of Georgia and the EU.  This Association Agreement has great potential for Georgia to become more integral to the process of European integration. I voted in favour of the proposals made in this motion because, in my opinion, it places an appropriate emphasis on reforming the judicial system and strengthening the rule of law and democracy.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - We abstained in the vote on the ASSOCIATION Agreement between the EU and Georgia for the reasons set out below. We respect the decision of the people of Georgia, who have shown their support for the European project, and we are in favour of the EU fostering cooperation ties with neighbouring countries. However, we are critical of the content of this Agreement, which, inter alia, imposes on Georgia a gradual process of adapting to the European framework without clear financial support and without the right to participate in the political process which in the future could lead it to be a full member of the EU. The motion for a Resolution implys that the accession process is accelerated through the signing of the agreement, although no EU enlargement will take place until 2020.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for a motion for a resolution on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and its Member States on the one hand and Georgia on the other, as that agreement constitutes a process of Georgia's social, economic and legal rapprochement with European principles and standards. I also support the creation of a free trade space between the European Union and Georgia that will contribute to the economic growth of that country.  This calls on Georgia to continue the democratic and comprehensive reforms that are necessary and must comply with the Treaty on European Union. However, I believe that further reforms and efforts are needed to stabilise the area at stake and to combat discrimination, human rights violations, corruption and other phenomena still present in Georgia.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I welcome the conclusion of this Association Agreement, which is a significant step forward in relations between the European Union and Georgia. This agreement is supported by 69% of the Georgian people, demonstrating the commitment of this people to cooperation with the European Union. I also welcome the European Parliament's reaffirming, through this resolution, its support for Georgia's sovereignty and territorial integrity. It is also important to encourage the Georgian authorities to continue their efforts in the area of democratic reforms, including the reform of the judicial system, and to work for national reconciliation.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — The Agreement is a very important step forward in our relations with Georgia. It must now be implemented in full so that the benefits and advantages of the agreement are felt by the people.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the Association Agreement between the European Union and Georgia because it is an agreement with a country which has shown for years that it wants to improve itself within a democratic process of structural reforms. I believe that agreements of this kind can reward efforts to protect fundamental human rights and promote democracy. Economic developments will also be remarkable, which will be able to help citizens in a positive way.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — I voted against this report which gives its approval to the conclusion of an Association Agreement with Georgia, which entails the creation of a large free trade area between the EU and Georgia. I have always voted against the creation of free trade zones between the EU and third countries on the understanding that they always benefit large companies and large European capital, to the detriment of local production by third countries. In this case it couldn't be any other way. Moreover, it has become clear that in the case of Georgia the intention is to bring Georgia closer to the orbit of the EU and NATO, and to move it as far away from Russia's influence as possible, which is an interference in Georgia's internal affairs. That's why I voted against it.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. — (DE) I abstained, even though there are many things right in this resolution. However, I do not agree with the claim that Georgia is a European state. This is clearly wrong according to geographical criteria, because Georgia is in the near east. It may be said that Georgia has a European tradition culturally. I would agree with that, but with this justification, Israel would probably also be a European state. I welcome the fact that Georgia is developing economically, democratically and in the rule of law by following the EU acquis. I also welcome the fact that Georgia, like Turkey, is participating in integration measures below the threshold of EU membership. However, I do not see any more European perspective for Georgia.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: in writing. — I voted for the ratification of the Association Agreement with Georgia. It is a step forward for a country which is struggling for democracy. We need to continue to support Georgia on its way to the European family, to resist the oppression of the Russian Federation and to overcome the consequences of internal conflicts in the breakaway regions of Abkhazia and South Ossetia. I support enhanced cooperation with Georgia’s reform efforts. The judicial system must become more independent and effective, fully functioning and properly staffed. Other specific objectives identified in the last report of Freedom House, such as confiscating criminal assets, convicting money launderers and targeting misuse of public funds should be encouraged and observed as metrics of success. While the government of Georgia has been taking important steps, the difficult task of fully implementing reforms still lies ahead. The EU should continue to push the Georgian Government, through the Association agenda, to continue the fight against organised crime, corruption, fraud and money laundering at all levels. I call on the Member States to ratify the Association Agreement as soon as possible, so that all its provisions can enter into force without delay.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — An association agreement between the European Union and Georgia, which simultaneously includes a free trade agreement, was initiated during the Eastern Partnership in Vilnius on 29 November 2013 and signed on 27 July 2014. The Parliament of the Republic of Georgia ratified the agreement a month later and approved the entry into force of the agreement from 1 September 2014.  The Association Agreement and the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area AA /DCFTA represent a new generation of agreements signed by the European Union with third countries. Both agreements aim to significantly deepen Georgia's political co-operation and economic integration with the European Union. The agreement contains binding rules for both sides. Particular attention will be paid to the implementation of activities through different areas.  The agreement envisions reforms in the following areas: public administration, justice and law enforcement, economic recovery and growth, consumer protection, energy, transport, environmental protection, industrial development, social development and protection, education, youth and culture. I supported this report because I believe that the agreement will improve cooperation in the area of strengthening the rule of law, fighting corruption, ensuring respect for fundamental human rights and freedoms and strengthening democratic institutions.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. — The European Parliament supports future political and economic reforms in Georgia. The Association Agreement opens up new opportunities for both Georgia and the European Union. It is also a sign of European solidarity with the Georgian people. I would like to underline that this partnership relationship is not directed against third countries, but is aimed at extending positive cooperation. This cooperation will benefit not only the European Union and Georgia, but also the whole region and Georgia's neighbours. I would like to thank once again the colleagues who took part in the preparation of this report and those who took part in the debate. Thank you all for the positive vote in the sitting and for the support of Georgia and the Georgian people.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I abstained from voting in the Mamikins report on the draft Council decision on the signing, on behalf of the European Union, of the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States, of the one part, and Georgia, on the other, because I do not consider that the political, geostrategic and economic conditions for the conclusion and subsequent implementation of that agreement have matured.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — I am opposed to an association agreement with Georgia for the same reasons as that with Moldova. In times of economic complications, it is not advisable to pump money from the European Union's already tight budget into countries in order to increase their competitiveness in the European internal market without bringing rapid improvements. Georgia, like Ukraine, needs long-term aid, which we cannot afford at this time. Furthermore, the political aspect of rapprochement with Georgia must be taken into account. As the example of Moldova shows, an association agreement with Georgia can lead to Russia imposing massive sanctions on that country. The Union would also have to be liable for the economic failures caused by this.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. Described as "one of the most ambitious free trade agreements that the European Union has ever negotiated with a third country", the agreement is also presented as a prelude to Georgia's accession to the European Union. I challenge any further enlargement under the current conditions, not wanting to subject other peoples to the austere ordeal of the European peoples. Moreover, it is a new act of preparation of hostilities with Russia, even though the report states that "association process does not pose any danger to Russia's political and economic interests". That it is referred to is enough to illuminate the emptied objective in reality. Such hypocrisy sickens me. I'm voting against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — There is a strong national and all-party consensus in Georgia in favour of integration in the West, including the EU and NATO. This consensus should help to mitigate the current polarisation of the political landscape and create the necessary conditions for constructive dialogue between the forces of the majority and the minority.  This Association Agreement is a significant step forward in EU-Georgia relations, which embodies a commitment to political association and economic integration. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — An Association Agreement between the European Union and the creation of Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area (DCFTA) between both parties would be beneficial to all involved. I therefore voted in favour of this agreement because of the growth, job creation, prosperity and stability such an agreement would bring to Georgia. Georgia will have to adapt its laws and standards so as to respect the common norms and values of the Union. This is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. The Association Agreement with Georgia is another step that strengthens the existing economic and trade cooperation framework. It will allow us to move towards a political association based on common values and norms and towards Georgia's economic integration into our internal market, through the establishment of a very ambitious free trade area, which will benefit the modernization of the country and the improvement of the quality of life of its citizens. We must continue to deepen this area of cooperation and dialogue on common interests, which will create trade opportunities for the Union and for Georgia, but also on important areas of foreign policy, security, freedom and justice. Georgia has made significant progress, and we must continue to show solidarity and support its reforms. The European Parliament, in collaboration with the Georgian Parliament, has a crucial role to play in ensuring the implementation of this agreement.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I supported this association agreement with Georgia as a tool for Georgia’s further democratisation and European integration.

name: Sorin MOISĂ
text: in writing. - Georgia is a long-standing, committed partner for Europe. It has been very stubborn in its intention to choose its own path in history. This vote is about respecting that freedom to choose.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. I voted against all the proposed amendments. The conclusion of the Association Agreement with Georgia is just one more manoeuvre put in place by the European Union to isolate Russia. After the promises of accession to Ukraine, will the Union do the same with Georgia?

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. — I believe that this non-legislative resolution welcomes the signature of the Association Agreement which marks a positive step forward in EU-Georgia relations. I also support judicial reforms in Georgia to make sure they comply with European standards as opposed to condemning them.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. — (IT) We welcome the signing of this Association Agreement, as it represents a significant step forward in relations between the European Union and Georgia and reaffirms the commitment of both parties to political association and economic integration. Georgia has made significant progress in the field of institutional reforms, with a view to further strengthening the stability, independence and effectiveness of the institutions responsible for guaranteeing democracy (in particular that of judicial institutions), the rule of law and good governance, as well as the consolidation of the system for the protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms. Although there is still much to be done, we note the efforts made by the Georgian authorities in the field of democratic reforms and believe that confidence should be given to the Georgian country and people.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I objected to this report, which plays the card of provocation in Georgia against the Russian neighbour, a situation perfectly similar to the proliferation of European association agreements with Moldova or Ukraine. Knowing the geopolitical tensions in the Caucasus region, I cannot endorse this report on the conclusion of the Association Agreement with Georgia.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I supported the motion for a resolution on the conclusion of the Association Agreement between the European Union and Georgia. Georgia has a strong link with the EU and NATO, and there is considerable agreement in the country to comply with the agreement. Although Georgia still has to work hard, it has so far been a prominent promoter of reform and a deepening of relations with the European Union. It is important to continue to clearly support georgia's territorial integrity.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — (IT) Ladies and gentlemen, Georgia has made considerable progress in strengthening relations with the European Union and has therefore benefited from additional financial allocations under the Integration and Cooperation Programme of the Eastern Partnership. The ratification of the Association Agreement is the beginning of a process of cooperation and cooperation aimed at ensuring greater stability on the continent. Cooperation in the South Caucasus is an essential element for the stability of the area and it is therefore necessary to preserve the balance of traditional economic relations in the region. Having said that, I would like to vote in favour.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — I support my colleague Miminkis' report on the conclusion of the Association Agreement with Georgia, which creates a framework for stronger political dialogue and deeper cooperation in a range of sectoral activities, as well as the harmonisation of Georgian legislation with the EU acquis.  As part of the EU Eastern Partnership policy, I believe that moving closer to the Union will help the country's security and solve problems in Abkhasia and South Ossetia. At the moment, the EU must show much more political will towards Georgia, as well as find a way to implement the difficult economic and political reforms in Georgia. It is not good for Georgia to qualify as a country where judicial institutions are used to deal with political opponents, and I call on the Georgian Government to engage experienced advisers from EU member states in judicial reforms that will contribute to the credibility of reforms to ensure the independence of the state attorney's office and strengthen the rule of law.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. — Following the European Parliament resolution of 12 March 2014 on the assessment and prioritisation of the EU's relations with the Eastern Partnership countries, I welcomed Georgia's significant progress in reforming and strengthening relations with the EU. However – and this is why I abstained – I believe that efforts are still needed to achieve national reconciliation and that a more thorough reform of the judicial system is carried out. I hope that the ratification of the agreement will help Georgia to move closer to EU rules and values.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Writing. — Although it is a positive development that Georgia, a country with undoubted European history and culture, is moving closer to the European Union, I am abstaining on the Association Agreement. If this were a genuine free trade agreement and the promotion of human rights, democracy and the rule of law, I would have my full support. However, this agreement mixes the interests of the EU and its Member States with those of NATO. Since I do not support the EU's pioneering of NATO, I am denying my support to the Association Agreement.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. "I vote in favour of such a resolution, as it congratulates Georgia and encourages it to continue its efforts against corruption and poverty. This country has made great progress despite past military events. I would also like to support this resolution, as it recalls Georgia's strategic interest in the European Union and its ever closer and fruitful collaboration with the West.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of concluding the Association Agreement between the EU and Georgia, because I believe that it provides important mutual benefits, representing a significant advance in deepening relations between the two Parties. In this context, it is important to highlight the trade pillar of the Agreement, which will lead to the creation of a Comprehensive and Deep Free Trade Area (FTAA) between the EU and Georgia, which will allow, on the one hand, to strengthen Georgia's access to the EU market, thus creating an opportunity for the country's economy to modernise and contributing to improving the quality of life of its citizens , and, on the other hand, to facilitate EU trade and improve its investment conditions in Georgia.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — I support this Resolution which accompanies the Recommendation on the Association Agreement with Georgia and in which we welcome the progress made in Abkhazia and South Ossetia, as well as in relations with Russia.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - We abstained in the vote on the ASSOCIATION Agreement between the EU and Georgia for the reasons set out below. We respect the decision of the people of Georgia, who have shown their support for the European project, and we are in favour of the EU fostering cooperation ties with neighbouring countries. However, we are critical of the content of this Agreement, which, inter alia, imposes on Georgia a gradual process of adapting to the European framework without clear financial support and without the right to participate in the political process which in the future could lead it to be a full member of the EU. The motion for a Resolution implys that the accession process is accelerated through the signing of the agreement, although no EU enlargement will take place until 2020.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. — I voted for this recommendation, which is part of the approval process for the Association Agreement/Free Trade Agreement between the European Union and Georgia. The agreement, launched during the Eastern Partnership Summit in Vilnius on 29 November 2013 and signed on 27 June 2014, provides for increased cooperation in strengthening the rule of law, promoting judicial reforms, combating corruption, ensuring respect for fundamental rights and freedoms and strengthening democratic institutions. It will also enable Georgia to modernise its trade relations with the EU and develop its economy through the phasing out of tariffs and quotas, and the harmonisation of laws, standards and regulations. Reforms include public governance, justice, policing, economic recovery and growth, consumer protection, energy, transport, environmental protection, industrial and social development, social protection, education, youth and culture.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — Georgia's closest rapprochement with the European Union, embodied in the Association Agreement we have adopted today in this Parliament and which includes a Comprehensive and Deep Free Trade Area, in addition to representing one of the most ambitious Free Trade Agreements that the European Union has ever negotiated with a third country, was signed in a broader framework of the Eastern Partnership, which included agreements with Moldova and Ukraine. This wider framework of external action by the European Union implies greater intervention and monitoring by Parliament in relation to our relations with third countries. This non-legislative report voted at the same time as the consent to the Agreement is part of this field of action of the European Parliament, the so-called parliamentary diplomacy, including a series of recommendations to our Eastern partner in which I see myself, and I therefore voted in favour.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution, which supports the ratification of the Association Agreement between the European Union and Georgia, which includes a comprehensive and comprehensive free trade agreement.  This agreement was made possible by Georgia's political and economic reforms, but it is not an end in itself. Thus, economic and democratic reforms must continue and the European Union and Georgia must maintain and deepen their relations.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. - We abstained in the vote on the ASSOCIATION Agreement between the EU and Georgia for the reasons set out below. We respect the decision of the people of Georgia, who have shown their support for the European project, and we are in favour of the EU fostering cooperation ties with neighbouring countries. However, we are critical of the content of this Agreement, which, inter alia, imposes on Georgia a gradual process of adapting to the European framework without clear financial support and without the right to participate in the political process which in the future could lead it to be a full member of the EU. The motion for a Resolution implys that the accession process is accelerated through the signing of the agreement, although no EU enlargement will take place until 2020.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - I voted against this report which gives its approval to the conclusion of an Association Agreement with Georgia, which means the creation of a large free trade area between the EU and Georgia. I have always voted against the creation of free trade zones between the EU and third countries on the understanding that they always benefit large companies and large European capital, to the detriment of local production by third countries. In this case it couldn't be any other way. Moreover, it has become clear that in the case of Georgia the intention is to bring Georgia closer to the orbit of the EU and NATO, and to move it as far away from Russia's influence as possible, which is an interference in Georgia's internal affairs. That's why I voted against it.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — Thanks to today’s vote, the motion for a non-legislative resolution on the conclusion of the Association Agreement between the EU, the European Atomic Energy Community and Georgia has been approved by Members. The signature of the Association Agreement constitutes a significant step forward in EU-Georgia relations and embodies a commitment to the path of political association and economic integration. The ratification of the Agreement is not the final goal in itself and full implementation in as short a timeframe as possible is key.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing - I voted in favour of this resolution because the agreement creates better conditions and opportunities for the further development of Euro-Georgian relations. I am very happy that the agreement removes trade barriers between Georgia and European countries, which can ultimately significantly kick-start the Georgian economy, which, like Slovakia, has recently been hit by anti-Russian sanctions. The Slovak Republic, the country where I come from, is interested in continuing its political support for Georgia to date and is ready to assist it in bilateral negotiations, in particular with regard to the transfer of transformative experiences in the area of building democratic institutions, establishing a rule of law, respect for human rights, supporting economic reforms and building civil society. I am convinced that the approval of the agreement will open up new perspectives and opportunities for firms in Georgia to strengthen their ties with the EU, and that the products produced in Georgia will thus find a more viable path to European markets, making Georgia a more attractive trading partner for European investors.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing — I am delighted with the successful vote on georgia's association agreement with the European Union. I support his pro-European efforts for the mutual benefit of eu and Georgian citizens.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — I supported the Association Agreement with Georgia as it focuses on integration, which will calm the political situation and create the need for constructive dialogue.  The European Union needs to strengthen solidarity with countries seeking to strengthen their independence after the Soviet Union. After the Rose Revolution, Georgia made progress in strengthening relations with the European Union, promoting human rights and democracy. The Eastern Partnership has created a strong policy framework to improve political relations. The European Union has decided to advocate for Georgia's rights and its accession to international organisations or alliances. Abolishing visas would mean a direct benefit to the population, while this is the most ambitious free trade agreement ever reached with a third country, if the countries of the European Economic Area are exempted.  This agreement is seen as a significant step for EU-Georgia relations. It also supports Georgia's political, social and economic recovery and marks a deepening of socio-economic cooperation with the EU.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — At a time when the economic crisis continues to exist, economic agreements with third countries, on favourable terms, do not contribute to solving the economic problems of the Member States; on the contrary, sharpens them.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. "I followed the party line and my colleague who specializes in the issue. The signing of the Association Agreement is expected to be a significant step forward in relations between the European Union and Georgia and will reflect the commitment to the method of political association and economic integration.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: in writing. — The Eastern Partnership project is aimed at achieving stability and prosperity in the Union's neighbourhood. It is mutually beneficial to further deepen relations between the European Union and Georgia as one of the partner countries. I therefore fully support the association agreement.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — We do not review ourselves in these free trade agreements which represent in our era a new form of colonialism in commercial and economic version. We oppose trade agreements not based on free trade, but based on mutual cooperation and respect for the specificity of all parties. Moreover, this agreement represents yet another chapter in the siege of Russia, thus seeking to break historical ties of cooperation that reflect not only geographical proximity, but also cultural identities. Only in this way do we understand the offensive purposes used to demonize Russia. We voted against it.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — Instead of taking care of its own concerns, the EU is once again making a mistake with an association agreement with Georgia, which highlights myopia, but also ignorance of the crisis in the EU. The money that is now available to Georgia is again lacking in the European internal market and in regions that have been hit hard by the crisis. The intention is once again clear in foreign policy matters, namely on a course of confrontation with Russia. Given that this agreement is, on the one hand, further straining diplomatic and economic relations with the Russian Federation, and that the money used for another bottomless barrel would be more urgently needed in Europe, I have firmly rejected this agreement.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: in writing. — I fully support the conclusion of the association agreement with Georgia. The country fully deserves such a step and is also very important for its further internal political development and further implementation of democratic reforms.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Madam President, I have already expressed my position, so I will only say one thought. It is good that this association agreement does not only contain economic issues, it not only addresses tariff and, say, free trade issues, but also addresses the rule of law in Georgia, that is, strengthening certain legal sectors, such as the subject of public procurement. I think that's very important.  As a former Minister of Justice in the Czech Republic, I know that association with Europe should not only be an economic issue, but also a matter of non-economic issues, first and foremost the development of the rule of law. I am therefore glad that this agreement also addresses these issues, which is why I supported it.

name: David COBURN
text: Madam President, I voted against the Association Agreement with Georgia. The EU empire-building and meddling in the former Soviet Union has triggered the crisis in the Ukraine. Not content with this, the EU is meddling in Georgia with this Association Agreement.  Georgia, as recently as 2008, was at war with Russia. UKIP feels that the EU is stoking the flame of conflict yet again. With the fall of oil prices, and consequently the rouble, Russia and its leadership are in a fragile state of mind so it is extremely unwise to provoke Mr Putin who, despite his economic reverses, has more tank divisions than the European Union which has exactly none. Baroness Ashton, a dangerous amateur EU Foreign Minister, or alleged Foreign Minister, wished to cast the shadow of war across Europe, and this was before the rouble fell. We do not want 1914 to be repeated in 2014 through EU empire-building. This is a very dangerous and foolish move to provoke the Russian bear.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: That concludes the oral explanations of votes. Written explanations of the vote

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — I voted against this report which gives its approval to the conclusion of an Association Agreement with Georgia, which entails the creation of a large free trade area between the EU and Georgia. I have always voted against the creation of free trade zones between the EU and third countries on the understanding that they always benefit large companies and large European capital, to the detriment of local production by third countries. In this case it couldn't be any other way. Moreover, it has become clear that in the case of Georgia the intention is to bring Georgia closer to the orbit of the EU and NATO, and to move it as far away from Russia's influence as possible, which is an interference in Georgia's internal affairs. That's why I voted against it.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. - This is a vote on consent for the Association Agreement between the EU and Georgia. If Georgia wants to enter into an AA with the EU then it is their sovereign right to do so. However, I believe agreement is likely to be to the detriment of the people of Georgia and will be unhelpful in de-escalating tensions in the region. For these reasons I abstained.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. — On 27 June 2014, Georgia and the EU signed an Association Agreement. This agreement is part of a new generation of association agreements with Eastern Partnership countries and contains provisions on a deep and comprehensive free trade area. It therefore goes beyond most free trade agreements, as non-tariff barriers have been removed, rules need to be aligned with those of the EU and binding rules on investment and services are included. In this way, Georgia will be integrated into the internal market, primarily in cooperation in areas such as foreign and security policy, justice, freedom and security. Following the association agreements with Ukraine and Moldova, the EU-Georgia Association Agreement is the third of its kind to be ratified by the European Parliament. In view of the fact that Russia intends to significantly increase its military and economic control in the breakaway Georgian territory of Abkhazia, the adoption of the agreement by the European Parliament is all the more welcome, as it reaffirms its support for Georgia's sovereignty and territorial integrity, thereby enabling Georgia to move closer to the EU in the future.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. — I welcome the Association Agreement with Georgia. Following such countries as Ukraine and Moldova, it marks a turning point for Georgia-EU relations. The agreement embodies not only the mutual benefits parties will get from a deep and comprehensive trade area and a common security and defence strategy but most importantly it marks Georgia’s commitment to a complex reform and cooperation process, which requires a lot of effort and political will to align Georgia’s laws and judiciary to EU legislation and involves public sector reform, in other words measures which will help Georgia to keep up with EU standards. I am convinced this agreement will lead to positive developments at all levels of state and civil society in Georgia and enhance bilateral EU-Georgia relations, providing Georgia with a modern European perspective.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of concluding an Association Agreement with Georgia. This association and free trade agreement is intended to strengthen the economic and political ties between the European Union and Georgia. It will become the third treaty of its kind that the European Parliament ratifies with the EU's eastern neighbours. In September this year, the Commission adopted a proposal for a directive on the protection of the environment and The EP has already ratified a similar treaty with Ukraine, and in November the European Parliament adopted a resolution calling on the European Parliament to take part in the agreement. – with Moldova. The creation of a comprehensive free trade area with the EU should increase market access to the EU's economic bloc through binding commitments on standards and common values, while the EU will benefit from smoother trade flows and better conditions for investment in Georgia. It is important that both Parties engage in constructive dialogue in order to confirm the main reforms and commitments provided for in the Association Agreement. The priorities set out in the Agreement should be adequately technically and financially supported in order to ensure that Georgia has the means to continue its democratic and economic reforms.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I voted against this association agreement, which is primarily part of the strategy of encircling Russia by the vassalisation of its historical and strategic partners. I am outraged that we have been forced to have the presence of the former Georgian President in the rostrum during the vote: Mr Saakashvili, who has dragged his people into an open war with Russia, is now living in exile in the United States, apparently to escape prosecution by his country's judicial authorities.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. " This agreement is an important step for Union-Georgia relations. While the country shows a real ambition to comply with the EU's acquis, a balanced free trade agreement will benefit both sides. Through this agreement, the European Union could benefit from facilitating trade and improving investment conditions in Georgia. For its part, after adapting to European requirements in terms of laws, standards and values, Georgia, in addition to seeing its political environment move all the more towards a democratic rule of law, will gain access to the European market and, as a result, strengthen its economy.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The recommendation on the Association Agreement between the EU and Georgia should enable the establishment of a vast free trade area (again one after those recently voted with Ukraine and Moldova) for the benefit mainly of Georgia, whose MEPs manage to quantify the growth of its GDP as a result of this agreement of 4.3%. From a European point of view, there are no figures on the concrete contribution of this agreement to the European economy. Moreover, it will only increase tensions between the Union and Russia, so I voted against it.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. — (SV) I have voted in favour of the agreement. However, I would like to stress that the people of Georgia should have had the decisive decision on this important issue. The best form of a populardecision on crucial issues is a referendum; at that time, the economic and social consequences of the agreement could also have been discussed in depth, as well as the consequences for relations with Russia.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — The Agreement with Georgia is the third in a new series of partnership agreements, after those signed with Ukraine and Moldova, to be ratified by Parliament. I have given my go-ahead to the Association Agreement between the European Union and Georgia which will mean greater political partnership and economic integration between the two sides, including the progressive opening of their respective markets.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this report because it supported the conclusion of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement on behalf of the European Union. The EU-Georgia Association Agreement is the most effective instrument for bilateral cooperation, helping Georgia to strengthen its political and economic stability, increase resilience to external threats and respond appropriately to the choice of people to link their future with the European Union.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. — This is a vote on consent for the Association Agreement between the EU and Georgia. If Georgia wants to enter into an AA with the EU then it is their sovereign right to do so. However, the agreement is likely to impoverish the people of Georgia, with escalating tensions in the region. For these reasons I abstained.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — Vote against: the agreement contains a trade pillar which will lead to the creation of a comprehensive and in-depth free trade area (DCFTA) with the EU, which provides for the complete elimination of all duties.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. — This is a vote on consent for the Association Agreement between the EU and Georgia.  If Georgia wants to enter into an Association Agreement with the EU then it is their sovereign right to do so.  However, the agreement is likely to impoverish the people of Georgia while escalating tensions in the region. For these reasons I abstained.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. - I voted against this proposal as this is an extension of EU influence in eastern Europe, which only exacerbates the current political tensions with the Russian Federation. I believe the EU needs to stop building its own, new empire. Least of all, on the Russian border.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. — By approving the Association Agreement we are sending a clear message to the government in Tbilisi that a commitment to building democracy in the country has to be duly implemented. There will be no excuses for the politically-biased prosecution of former politicians who are being detained. Prosecuting the political opposition is unacceptable. We expect the ruling coalition to strengthen the rule of law and build democracy in the country. There is no other alternative.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of this recommendation so that this agreement can allow Georgia to significantly increase its market access to the EU while, conversely, the EU will benefit from easier trade flows and better investment conditions in Georgia. This is an extremely important vote because all this will facilitate the modernisation of the economy, the stabilisation of EU investment in Georgia and contribute to a better business environment for small and medium-sized enterprises as well.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — This Agreement is very favourable for the Member States, while the EU will benefit from smoother commercial flows and better investment conditions in Georgia. I voted in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — I voted against this report which gives its approval to the conclusion of an Association Agreement with Georgia, which entails the creation of a large free trade area between the EU and Georgia. I have always voted against the creation of free trade zones between the EU and third countries on the understanding that they always benefit large companies and large European capital, to the detriment of local production by third countries. In this case it couldn't be any other way. Moreover, it has become clear that in the case of Georgia the intention is to bring Georgia closer to the orbit of the EU and NATO, and to move it as far away from Russia's influence as possible, which is an interference in Georgia's internal affairs. That's why I voted against it.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — By establishing a Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area (DCFTA) with the EU, Georgia should increase its market access to the largest economic block, by taking binding commitments on the adoption of laws, standards and common values, whilst the EU will benefit from smoother commercial flows and better investment conditions in Georgia. I believe in strengthening relations between the European Union and neighbouring countries the likes of Georgia, hence I voted in favour of this Association Agreeement.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. — The EU-Georgia Association Agreement was initiated during the Eastern Partnership Summit in Vilnius on 29 November 2013 and signed on 27 June 2014. The Georgian Parliament ratified it on 18 July, allowing the agreement to enter into force provisionally on 1 September 2014. This agreement aims to significantly deepen Georgia's political association and gradual economic integration into the EU's internal market. The Association Agreement also provides for many opportunities for sectoral cooperation and focuses on supporting key reforms, economic recovery and growth, governance and sectoral cooperation in 28 areas, including agriculture and rural development. Given the current geopolitical context in Eastern Europe and the Caucasus, this association agreement charts a European path for Georgia. For this reason, I am voting for this agreement.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. — Through these association agreements, the European Union continues its diplomatic errors which, in the current context of geopolitical tensions, are more akin to alignment with American positions than in the search for prospects for pacified international relations in this region of the Caucasus. Refusing to let France and the European Union be used as a relay for the ambitions of the United States in Georgia, I voted against this text.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. — I supported the recommendation for a draft Council decision on the conclusion of the EU-EC Atomic Energy Association Agreement with their Member States and Georgia, as I agree with the arguments put forward by the rapporteur that this agreement is one of the most ambitious in the area of free trade. The aim of establishing this comprehensive and in-depth area is to facilitate Georgia's access to one of the strongest economies in the world in exchange for specific commitments and the adoption of legislation, as well as the improvement of common values.  I believe that the Association Agreement will have a positive effect on the implementation of reforms in the country and contribute to its pro-European development. For these reasons, I welcome this Parliament's decision to support its conclusion.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — I voted against the recommendation, as the enlargement of the trading partners (with third countries looking forward to EU membership) serves only the interests of the economically powerful states, without resolving the crisis affecting the countries of the South, while, in the long term, it will bring economic consequences to the Contracting Third States equivalent to those experienced by our country.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — It is proposed to vote against the recommendation, as the enlargement of the trading partners (with third countries looking forward to EU membership) serves only the interests of the economically powerful states, without resolving the crisis affecting the countries of the South, while in the long term it will have economic consequences equivalent to those experienced by our country.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. — The EU’s meddling in the former Soviet Union has triggered crisis in the Ukraine. Not content with this, the EU is meddling in Georgia, a country that as recently as 2008 was at war with Russia. We feel the EU is stoking the flame of conflict and mistrust this agreement. An association agreement is a halfway house to full EU membership. We can see where this is going, and so can Russia. Poking the Russian bear is not a good idea. Especially when the EU does not as yet have an army.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. — By joining the deep and comprehensive free trade area within the framework of the Agreement concluded under the auspices of the Eastern Partnership, Georgia voted in favour of adopting legislation, standards and common values. While Georgia will have market access to the largest trading bloc, the EU will enjoy better conditions for trade relations and more favourable investment conditions in Georgia. By my vote, I have contributed to the modernisation of the Georgian economy, the consolidation of EU investment and a more predictable political and regulatory environment.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for a draft legislative resolution on the council's draft decision on the conclusion of the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States, on the one hand, and Georgia, on the other because by intensifying and formalising relations with Georgia, it contributes to the peace and stability of the region, thereby confirming Georgia's sovereignty and territorial integrity. I support the European Union's efforts to achieve national reconciliation in Georgia, where the situation is still tense and where an atmosphere of freedom and democracy needs to be created. I therefore believe that the Agreement will actively contribute to the development of Georgia and building stronger economic ties with the EU.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I welcome the conclusion of this Association Agreement, which is a significant step forward in relations between the European Union and Georgia. This agreement is supported by 69% of the Georgian people, demonstrating the commitment of this people to cooperation with the European Union. I also welcome the European Parliament's reaffirming, through this resolution, its support for Georgia's sovereignty and territorial integrity. It is also important to encourage the Georgian authorities to continue their efforts in the area of democratic reforms, including the reform of the judicial system, and to work for national reconciliation.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — I am pleased that Parliament ratified the EU-Georgia Association Agreement. This deal will form the backbone of strengthened political association and economic integration between the EU and Georgia and help the country to develop further, economically and socially, creating new opportunities and decent work for all.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. — (IT) I supported Mr President, I should like to thank the Rapporteur for his excellent report. Mamikins because it concerns an agreement that will have a significant positive impact both on georgia's economy and for the European Union. I am generally in favour of agreements that take into account the development opportunities of countries that want to have trade relations with the EU, provided that all the reciprocity clauses and safety standards necessary to protect our consumers and to ensure the competitiveness of our businesses are respected.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — I voted against this report which gives its approval to the conclusion of an Association Agreement with Georgia, which entails the creation of a large free trade area between the EU and Georgia. I have always voted against the creation of free trade zones between the EU and third countries on the understanding that they always benefit large companies and large European capital, to the detriment of local production by third countries. In this case it couldn't be any other way. Moreover, it has become clear that in the case of Georgia the intention is to bring Georgia closer to the orbit of the EU and NATO, and to move it as far away from Russia's influence as possible, which is an interference in Georgia's internal affairs. That's why I voted against it.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the Association Agreement because the agreement on a free trade area and Georgia's commitments to the rule of law and democracy made in the agreement are right and important. This agreement will bring considerable progress, particularly for the citizens of Georgia. I do not think it is right for the agreement to claim that Georgia is a European state. This is clearly wrong according to geographical criteria, because Georgia is in the near east. It may be said that Georgia has a European tradition culturally. I would agree with that, but with this justification, Israel would probably also be a European state. I do not think it is right to enshrine in the association agreement a provision on Georgia's membership of Europe, because these two things have nothing in common: the EU has also concluded association agreements with many non-European states. However, given the great real benefits of the agreement, particularly for citizens, I have put aside my concerns about the classification of Georgia to Europe. Instead, I declare my objection in this statement. I am also abstaining on the resolution on this, because it also claims Georgia's membership of Europe.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — I support this report and the strengthening of relations between the European Union and Georgia.   It is important that Georgia continues to decisively implement judicial reforms, strengthen the rule of law and achieve a higher degree of democracy. Georgian sovereignty must not be compromised at any time, and all neighbouring states must respect Georgia's territorial integrity within internationally recognised borders.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. — The European Parliament’s ratification of the Association Agreement with Georgia has opened a new chapter in European Union relations with Georgia. Georgia has made significant progress in reforms and strengthening its relations with the EU. We welcome recent judicial reforms designed to strengthen Georgia’s democratic institutions and support the efforts of Georgian society to achieve further democratisation. Although much work remains to be done, experience shows that Georgians prefer to solve their problems, not to avoid them. I think that Europe should now show its real solidarity with Georgia and its people.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I abstained from voting in the Mamikins report on the draft Council decision on the signing, on behalf of the European Union, of the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States, of the one part, and Georgia, on the other, because I do not consider that the political, geostrategic and economic conditions for the conclusion and subsequent implementation of that agreement have matured.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the report signed by Mr Mamikins, in the hope that this agreement will offer Georgia a future in the European family. This agreement, which provides for the creation of a global free trade area, benefits the country substantially, allowing it easier access to the market. It will help, on the one hand, to make Georgia's trade flows with the European Union easier and, on the other, to ensure better investment conditions for EU Member States.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — I am opposed to an association agreement with Georgia for the same reasons as that with Moldova. In times of economic complications, it is not advisable to pump money from the European Union's already tight budget into countries in order to increase their competitiveness in the European internal market without bringing rapid improvements. Georgia, like Ukraine, needs long-term aid, which we cannot afford at this time. Furthermore, the political aspect of rapprochement with Georgia must be taken into account. As the example of Moldova shows, an association agreement with Georgia can lead to Russia imposing massive sanctions on that country. The Union would also have to be liable for the economic failures caused by this.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — This agreement negotiated under the Eastern Partnership is only intended to weaken Russia. Georgia has been the neoliberal laboratory of the United States and the Union on Russia's borders for ten years. This agreement aims to create a "deep and comprehensive free trade area" with the European Union, which should bring people happiness. When one sees the results of the policies carried out in Europe, one can wonder about the eagerness of the Georgian authorities to see the same suffering inflicted on its people. Out of sympathy for the Georgian people, I vote against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — There is a strong national and all-party consensus in Georgia in favour of integration in the West, including the EU and NATO. This consensus should help to mitigate the current polarisation of the political landscape and create the necessary conditions for constructive dialogue between the forces of the majority and the minority.  This Association Agreement is a significant step forward in EU-Georgia relations, which embodies a commitment to political association and economic integration. I hope that the conclusion of this agreement will be beneficial to all and contribute to the development of Georgia and to the consolidation of its democracy. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this recommendation because I believe that it is important that the Association Agreement (AA) between the Union and Georgia moves forward. There is strong cross-party support and wide popular approval for the AA in Georgia and it is essential that the EU does its part to ensure that the socioeconomic benefits of the AA start being felt in Georgia as soon as possible.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I supported the association agreement with Georgia as a tool for Georgia’s further democratisation and European integration.

name: Sorin MOISĂ
text: in writing. - — Georgia is a long standing, committed partner for Europe. It has been very stubborn in its intention to choose its own path in history. This Agreement is enshrining the free choice of free peoples, democratically represented.

name: Sophie MONTEL
