text: In writing. The European Union definitely does not know what to invent in an attempt to isolate Russia. This association agreement with Georgia is part of the arsenal of anti-Russian measures developed by the Union. It should be noted that the European Union has also already made free trade agreements, notably with Moldova, and has given Ukraine a promise of future accession. I voted against this association agreement with Georgia.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Association Agreement between the European Union and Georgia as I support the EU enlargement process and Georgia's European course.  Georgia has a European future, and as a Romanian MEP, I believe it is our duty to support the process of European integration of this state which shares common European values.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I objected to this report, which plays the card of provocation in Georgia against the Russian neighbour, a situation perfectly similar to the proliferation of European association agreements with Moldova or Ukraine. Knowing the geopolitical tensions in the Caucasus region, I cannot endorse the Union's association agreement with Georgia.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I supported the ratification of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement because it will help to make the Georgian economy more modern and predictable, benefiting both parties and all the Member States of the European Union.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — The Association Agreement with Georgia will not only strengthen relations with the EU, ensuring mutual benefits through wider market access, but will also facilitate the alignment of Georgian and European legislation. Cross-cutting sectoral cooperation is a key element for Georgia's socio-economic growth and the development of long-term cooperation between the parties. Having said that, I would like to vote in favour.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — The conclusion of the EU-Georgian Association Agreement is important for sending a message of solidarity to the Georgian people, supporting georgia's territorial integrity facing two frozen conflicts, as well as continuing political, economic and legal reforms. By joining, Georgia will gradually accept EU standards and standards, leading to stronger trade and strengthening economic relations. In parallel with stressing the importance of implementing the Agreement with Georgia, I would also stress the importance of further reforms and the achievement of results by the Georgian Government, in particular in the area of justice.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. — (IT) I preferred to abstain on the conclusion of the Association Agreement (AA) between the European Union and Georgia, because, although I am in favour of the creation of a comprehensive and in-depth free trade area (DCFTA) between the EU and Georgia, I believe that some of the conditions required are not fully met in order to allow full access to the EU market, and to ensure that both parties benefit from the trade flows provided for in the agreement.  I hope that Georgia will soon be in line with the EU acquis, which will contribute to the modernisation of the economy, the stabilisation of EU investment in Georgia and a better and more dynamic business environment.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Writing. — Although it is a positive development that Georgia, a country with undoubted European history and culture, is moving closer to the European Union, I am abstaining on the Association Agreement. If this were a genuine free trade agreement and the promotion of human rights, democracy and the rule of law, I would have my full support. However, this agreement mixes the interests of the EU and its Member States with those of NATO. Since I do not support the EU's pioneering of NATO, I am denying my support to the Association Agreement.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — Strengthening relations with Georgia is of great interest to both the European Union and Georgia. It is a strategic country, with 30% of its imports of European origin. I therefore vote for such a recommendation. Closer relations should enable greater exchanges and confidence in the Union's eastern partners, as well as the establishment of common trade and democratic standards.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — In recent years, Georgia has made significant progress in reforms and strengthening relations with the EU. In the context of this process, the conclusion of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement and the establishment, in this context, of the Comprehensive and Deep Free Trade Area (FTAA) are of fundamental importance, either for the reciprocal benefits they generate for the Parties or as a sign of recognition of the efforts made by the Georgian authorities to strengthen the stability and independence of the institutions and consolidate the rule of law and the system of protection of fundamental rights. Once the Agreement has been concluded, it is now necessary to ensure its implementation and to continue its reform efforts, in particular as regards the creation of the conditions for the construction of a free society based on democratic values and for the strengthening of the independence of the judiciary, which in no case should be used as an instrument of political revenge.  It should also be noted that Russia should fully respect Georgia's sovereignty and territorial integrity, to revoke the recognition of the separation of Abkhazia and the Tskhinvali/South Ossetia region, to end the occupation of these territories and to make a commitment not to use force against Georgia.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. — Reason for voting against: The EU meddling in the former Soviet Union has triggered the crisis in Ukraine. Not content with this, the EU is meddling in Georgia, a country that as recently as 2008 was at war with Russia. We feel the EU is stoking the flame of conflict and mistrust with this agreement.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — The Agreement with Georgia is the third in a new series of partnership agreements, after those signed with Ukraine and Moldova, to be ratified by Parliament. I have given my go-ahead to the Association Agreement between the European Union and Georgia as it will mean greater political partnership and economic integration between the two sides, which will lead to the progressive opening of their respective markets.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. — I voted for this recommendation, which is part of the approval process for the Association Agreement/Free Trade Agreement between the European Union and Georgia. The agreement, launched during the Eastern Partnership Summit in Vilnius on 29 November 2013 and signed on 27 June 2014, provides for increased cooperation in strengthening the rule of law, promoting judicial reforms, combating corruption, ensuring respect for fundamental rights and freedoms and strengthening democratic institutions. It will also enable Georgia to modernise its trade relations with the EU and develop its economy through the phasing out of tariffs and quotas and the harmonisation of laws, standards and regulations. Reforms include public governance, justice, policing, economic recovery and growth, consumer protection, energy, transport, environmental protection, industrial and social development, social protection, education, youth and culture.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. — I strongly support the draft resolution and I call on colleagues to vote in favour unequivocally. Georgia may not be so important economically, but a very important outpost of European values in the East. This country has voluntarily chosen the path of integration with Europe and has remained true to European values, even under pressure from Russia. EU support for Georgia is currently low, but the way in which this country uses good EU experience for its modernisation is a prime example for many other EU partner countries. Georgia is one of the undoubted leaders of the EU Neighbourhood Policy and we must support it. At the same time, I would like to make a few comments on the text of the resolution. Firstly, I believe that it does not sufficiently address the importance of public awareness of EU issues. Secondly, although paragraph 43 attempts to propose a solution to regional economic integration, it does not unnecessarily ignore Turkey and the EU's ability to encourage economic cooperation with Georgia by this candidate for eu accession.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — The Association Agreement between the European Union and Georgia, negotiated under the aegis of the Eastern Partnership between 2012 and 2013, provides for the creation of a Comprehensive and Deep Free Trade Area (FTAD) which constitutes mutual benefits.  Georgia, pledging to make binding commitments to adopt common legislation, standards and values, will provide a more stable, predictable and scrutinisable legal framework for its citizens, as well as improve its access to the world's largest trading bloc.  For its part, the EU will benefit from a greater fluidity in trade flows and better investment conditions in this country, promoting the modernisation of the economy and providing a more favourable and predictable political environment.  The FTAA is expected to increase trade between the EU and Georgia by 12% for Georgia's exports to the EU and around 7.5% for EU imports, improving georgia's current account situation. I therefore voted in favour of the conclusion of this Agreement.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. — I supported this recommendation of the European Parliament, which represents the ratification of the association agreement between the European Union and Georgia. Following the signing of the Association Agreement between the European Union and Georgia on 27 June and the ratification by the Georgian Parliament of the agreement on 18 July, the European Parliament was in turn required to approve the agreement. I welcome this approval. This association agreement will strengthen economic and political relations between the European Union and Georgia, and it also contains a trade component that will open up free access to markets on both sides in the long term.  It will be important to remain vigilant and ensure that the agreement is fully implemented and respected.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. — (IT) I have chosen to vote against because the agreement aims to eliminate all import duties and to prohibit the imposition of export duties on almost all types of goods by the EU, thus harming European companies.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - I voted against this report which gives its approval to the conclusion of an Association Agreement with Georgia, which means the creation of a large free trade area between the EU and Georgia. I have always voted against the creation of free trade zones between the EU and third countries on the understanding that they always benefit large companies and large European capital, to the detriment of local production by third countries. In this case it couldn't be any other way. Moreover, it has become clear that in the case of Georgia the intention is to bring Georgia closer to the orbit of the EU and NATO, and to move it as far away from Russia's influence as possible, which is an interference in Georgia's internal affairs. That's why I voted against it.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — Thanks to today’s vote, the motion for a non-legislative resolution on the conclusion of the Association Agreement between the EU, the European Atomic Energy Community and Georgia has been approved by Members. The signature of the Association Agreement constitutes a significant step forward in EU-Georgia relations and embodies a commitment to the path of political association and economic integration. The ratification of the Agreement is not the final goal in itself and full implementation in as short a timeframe as possible is key.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing - In 2004, Georgia, together with Armenia and Azerbaijan, was taken into the Neighbourhood Policy Project, through which the EU seeks to assist them in their economic, political and democratic reforms. Since then, Georgia has gone through significant stages of development, and I am pleased to say today that Georgia, with its 4.9 million people with an estimated GDP growth of 6.3%, unemployment of 13.7% and GDP per capita of $6 100 in 2014, is 1 among the most successful countries in the region in terms of the necessary reforms. I voted in favour of the resolution on the conclusion of the Association Agreement between the European Union and Georgia because I believe that this agreement will help Georgia to adopt the relevant laws and standards, which will become an appropriate instrument for strengthening the interrelationships between the EU and Georgia.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. — I support this proposal for an Association Agreement between the European Union and Georgia.  The importance of the FTA is reflected in providing Georgia with access to the market with the largest economic bloc, commercial flows and better investment conditions. One of the objectives of the Agreement is to reform Georgian trade policy that will bring a better and more predictable working environment, Georgia's economic integration into the EU, increasing contacts and mobility of people. This Agreement also supports the political, social and economic efforts to increase Georgia's energy security and environmental protection and deepen socio-economic cooperation with the EU.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — At a time when the economic crisis continues to exist, economic agreements with third countries, on favourable terms, do not contribute to solving the economic problems of the Member States; on the contrary, sharpens them.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. — By giving its approval to this association agreement, the European Parliament will enable Georgia to move closer to the European Union. We voted in favour of this agreement and took note of the ratification on 18 July of the agreement by the Georgian Parliament, which paves the way for its provisional application as early as 1 September 2014. It should be noted that the Association Agreement will only be a success if it is scrupulously implemented by both partners. The EU should therefore assist Georgia in adopting the necessary laws and decrees and ensuring their proper implementation.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: in writing. — The Eastern Partnership project is aimed at achieving stability and prosperity in the Union's neighbourhood. It is mutually beneficial to further deepen relations between the European Union and Georgia as one of the partner countries. I therefore fully support the association agreement.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — The Association Agreement (AA) between the European Union (EU) and Georgia, negotiated under the eastern partnership between 2012 and 2013, follows the model of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement, which is the most ambitious free trade agreement ever negotiated by the EU with a third country, without regard to the countries of the European Economic Area, with the creation of a Comprehensive and Deep Free Trade Area (CLAFT) with the EU. We do not review ourselves in these free trade agreements which represent in our era a new form of colonialism in the commercial and economic version. We oppose trade agreements not based on free trade, but based on mutual cooperation and respect for the specificity of all parties. Moreover, this agreement represents yet another chapter in the siege of Russia, thus seeking to break historical ties of cooperation that reflect not only geographical proximity, but also cultural identities. Only in this way do we understand the offensive purposes used to demonize Russia. We voted against it.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — Instead of taking care of its own concerns, the EU is once again making a mistake with an association agreement with Georgia, which highlights myopia, but also ignorance of the crisis in the EU. The money that is now available to Georgia is again lacking in the European internal market and in regions that have been hit hard by the crisis. The intention is once again clear in foreign policy matters, namely on a course of confrontation with Russia. Given that this agreement is, on the one hand, further straining diplomatic and economic relations with the Russian Federation, and that the money used for another bottomless barrel would be more urgently needed in Europe, I have firmly rejected this agreement.
